headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Pamela Padgett, Vi
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Sheldon Fox, Seni
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our second quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; Mick Lopez, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Sheldon Fox, Senior Vice President, Integration Engineering. 
But first, a few words on forward-looking. Forward-looking statements made today involve assumptions, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. For more information in related discussion, please see the press release, the presentation of Harris' SEC filings. In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed today to comparable GAAP measures is included on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com, where a replay of this call is also available. 
Okay, with that, Bill, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Pam, and good morning, everybody. Our second quarter and first half results are largely in line with our expectations for how fiscal '16 would've unfold. While Q2 revenue was a bit weaker than expected, we anticipate operating within the
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Pam, and good morning, everybody. Our second quarter and first half results are largely in line with our expectations for how fiscal '16 would've unfold. While Q2 revenue was a bit weaker than expected, we anticipate operating within the continuing soft revenue environment, with Q2 being the weakest of the year relative to prior year results due to the budget process and a difficult compare in the legacy Exelis business. And as we previously communicated, our #1 priority this year would be integrating Exelis and realizing the synergy savings and earnings accretion we promised and we're executing well against that goal. We're also delivering on our commitment to maximize free cash flow to quickly delever and to dispassionately evaluate portfolio reshaping as today's announcements and results will demonstrate. 
Second quarter earnings were solid, and free cash flow was particularly strong, and again, this quarter, we made excellent progress in achieving integration savings. We've also identified the additional opportunities and now expect to reach run rate savings exiting fiscal '17 of $140 million to $150 million, significantly higher than the $120 million we previously communicated. First half free cash flow was supporting our deleveraging priority, reducing term loan debt $200 million in the quarter and $383 million since closing the transaction in late May. 
We're also pleased to report being far down the path of divesting the aerostructures business, which was part of the Exelis acquisition and was determined to not be strategic to Harris. Aerostructures is currently reported within the electronic system segment and had calendar '15 revenue of $77 million. After receiving considerable interest from potential buyers, we are narrowing the group to a select few and expect to reach a definitive agreement soon. 
We'll also continue to evaluate our now much broader portfolio with the dispassionate view towards which businesses are strategically aligned and which are not. We also continue to adapt to market conditions and adjust our cost structure accordingly as we have in the past. In the second quarter, due to the prolonged downturn in CapRock's energy market, we took a noncash write-down of goodwill and other assets, and we launched restructuring and other actions that were primarily in CapRock. Our goal is to rightsize the business in line with market conditions, and these latest actions reduce their headcount by about 20%. When combined with steps we took in Q4 last year, headcount at CapRock will be down about 35% over the last 18 months. Altogether, these actions are expected to generate modest savings in fiscal '16 and about $20 million to $25 million in fiscal '17. 
So let me turn quickly to quarterly results in Slide 3 in the presentation, and I remind you that our discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis. Earnings per share was $1.49, with acquisition savings supporting operating performance in a still relatively soft revenue environment, with the recently reenacted R&D tax credit contributing $0.10 per share. Reported revenue was $1.84 billion compared to $1.21 billion in the prior year. In an organic basis, while we anticipate in a difficult year-over-year revenue compare, it was a little weaker than expected at down 14%, so let me give you a little more color on the drivers. About 4 to 5 points of the decline related to Exelis overdrive in their Q4 '14 results, Government IT Services contributed another 5 points, which as we mentioned before would be impacted by the wind-down of a couple of large contracts in a still slow procurement environment, and CapRock with another point or so with the remaining business contributing about 3 points. 
On the positive side, Harris legacy international tactical revenue was up a strong 10% in the quarter, resulting in Harris total legacy tactical revenue at about flat with the prior year and about as expected for the quarter. Revenue was also higher in geospatial imagery, driven by the continued ramp of our large classified foundation, geo and content management program, and was also higher with the FAA, driven by NextGen modernization programs. On a sequential basis for the company, revenue was up 2% with all segments higher except Critical Networks, which includes IT Services and CapRock. 
Orders in the quarter were $1.5 billion, and together with strong orders booked in Q1, first half book-to-bill with just over 1. In IT Services, although revenue was down in the quarter, orders were encouraging, driving a book-to-bill of 1.1 for the quarter in the first half. And we expect first half orders, combined with incumbent positions on existing programs, will support back half revenue stability. 
In CapRock, our strategy to diversify our business into the cruise market where bandwidth demand is growing is helping to offset a bit of the energy revenue weakness. Over the last 2 years, bandwidth demand on cruise ships has increased exponentially from an average of less than 5 megabits per ship to now 35 megabits with 1 gigabit in sight for the largest vessels. And it's important to note that our position in the cruise market is solid, with 2.5 years left on our 5-year agreement with Carnival and another 5 years left with Royal Caribbean following a contract extension that was awarded in the quarter. Perhaps as important, diversification brings a significant volume leverage for purchasing satellite bandwidth, and our scale has allowed us to consolidate bandwidth, drive down cost and implement a sales approach of one price over one global system regardless of market to further drive efficiency gains in the organization. 
In Tactical Communications, we previously highlighted U.S. funding support for foreign military sales from both the base budget as well as from accounts for special initiatives such as the European Reassurance Initiative, the Counterterrorism Partnerships Fund for Middle East and Africa, and the Iraq Train and Equip Fund or ITEF. The funding supports our strong 1Q bookings, and in 2Q, we booked $66 million in orders supported by ITEF. We ended the first half of the year with an international tactical book-to-bill of 0.99. On the U.S. tactical front, progress continues to be made on Army modernization, and we were encouraged that the Army requested best and final offers from all bidders for the 2-channel Manpack radio and reconfirm to their calendar Q1 award date. 
In Public Safety, orders were up more than 30% on a weak prior year compare, with book-to-bill greater than 1 on a fairly good revenue level of $109 million. Orders included $20 million from Arizona Public services, the state's largest electrical utility company; and $18 million from the International Guard that includes our latest product offering, the multiband XL 200P radio. While we're still not satisfied with our Public Safety results, we've expressed multiple times that improving performance in the business will come as a result of solving basic execution challenges, introducing new products, improving quality, strengthening front line and program management capabilities, and we're beginning to see positive signs that the business is slowly turning the corner. 
In space and Intel, on top of strong Q1 wins from classified customers, we received healthy orders of $172 million and another $23 million contract to support space superiority missions. Space superiority and protection has become a U.S. defense priority and is expected to receive $8 billion in funding over the next 5 years. Our first half win in space superiority, combined with the strong funding support, should make this an area of solid growth for the company into the future. 
And following the close of the quarter, the space and Intel segment was awarded a $316 million follow-on contract for NASA for the cross-track infrared sounder or CRISP payloads on the third and fourth weather satellites for the Joint Polar Satellite System. These payloads provide key global data used by the National Weather Service, and for Harris, the award continues the strong customer relationship we enjoy with NASA and with NOA. And then just recently in Critical Networks, we were awarded a 9-year, $44 million contract from U.K. navigation service provider called NATS to modernize their voice communications infrastructure. This represents our first international win in this area and results from leveraging technology provided under the FAA's NextGen modernization program to now address the global market. 
So with the successful integration of Excelis as our #1 focus for the company, I've asked Sheldon to join us again this quarter to provide a little more detail in integration and any additional opportunities the team has identified. Sheldon?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. If you turn to Slide 4. Again, this quarter, we made excellent progress in achieving integration savings and have identified several new opportunities. The team quickly developed plans to capture these addition
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. If you turn to Slide 4. Again, this quarter, we made excellent progress in achieving integration savings and have identified several new opportunities. The team quickly developed plans to capture these additional savings, and we're pleased to report that 100% of our cost-saving projects are either complete or in progress. As Bill noted earlier, we now expect net run rate savings to be in the range of $140 million to $150 million as we exit fiscal '17, up significantly from our previous estimate of $120 million. Associated with this, we now expect wrote integration cost of $250 million and net cost of $200 million after government reimbursements. Additional savings are primarily in 2 areas: rationalization and supply chain. 
In the Q1 call, we highlighted the SINCGARS tactical radio manufacturing operations from Fort Wayne to Rochester. And just last week, we completed production for our very first SINCGARS radio assembly in our Rochester state-of-the-art manufacturing facility. With this project well underway, we've launched new facilities consolidation projects in 5 locations that will reduce footprint by an additional 230,000 square feet, bringing total company's square footage reduction related to the acquisition down 15% since closing. 
The second area of additional savings comes from a thorough review of our supply chain. We've spent a lot of time building the database to what Exelis buys to what Harris buys and what each pays on price, down to the individual part number to understand our supply chain spending across the combined company. With this database in place, we launched multiple projects across a broad range of spend categories from electronic components to company travel to eliminate price disparity and leverage our much larger volume to reduce costs. We also launched should-cause analyses and value-engineering initiatives to further drive supply chain savings. A quick example is the should-cause analysis that identified a 20% reduction in the price of a key component used across our night vision product line. We see a lot of opportunities like these, which will add to our pipeline of regular annual operational excellence projects. And while not highlighted on the page, an underlying core theme of our integration is to reduce complexity throughout the company, and we're using this opportunity to take the best of both companies' approach to simplify and standardize across the new Harris. We've already reduce the number of health plans by 50%, corporate policies by 40% and legal entities by 12%. And we're targeting a 50% reduction in core IT applications and an even greater reduction in the number of data centers. So as we enter the back half of the first year of integration, we're excited about the progress so far and confident that driving standardization and simplification across the business will build a solid foundation for the future. 
And with that, I'll turn over to  Mick to discuss segment results.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sheldon, and good morning to everyone. Before turning to each segment, we'll provide some color around the onetime items in the quarter that are excluded from our non-GAAP results and also point you to GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations on Slide
componenttext:
Thank you, Sheldon, and good morning to everyone. Before turning to each segment, we'll provide some color around the onetime items in the quarter that are excluded from our non-GAAP results and also point you to GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations on Slide 5. 
Unrelated to the acquisition, we had a $367 million noncash charge to write down goodwill and other assets in the CapRock business as a result of the prolonged downturn in the energy market. Acquisition-related items included a $101 million benefit for a net liability reduction for certain post-employment benefit plans, $43 million of integration cost and a $3 million charge related to inventory step-up. We also had restructuring and other charges totaling $35 million, with the majority for workforce and facility reductions. 
So turning now to segment detail on Slide 6 and comparisons to prior year pro forma results as if Exelis and Harris were combined for all of fiscal '15. Communication Systems' segment revenue was $489 million compared to prior year pro forma of $539 million. Tactical Communications revenue was down 10%, declining primarily due to weakness in Exelis legacy, tactical and night vision product lines. Harris legacy Tactical Communications was about flat as a result of strength in international. 
Public Safety revenue was $109 million compared to $116 million in the prior year, declining year-over-year but up 18% sequentially quarter-to-quarter. Operating income in the second quarter was $138 million, and operating margin was 28.2% compared to last year's operating income of $144 million and 26.7% margin. 
Turning to space and intelligence systems on Slide 7. Second quarter revenue was $446 million compared to prior year pro forma of $488 million. Higher revenue from 2 classified programs, including the Foundation GEOINT Content Management program was more than offset by the completion of other classified programs and lower GPS3 revenue. Operating income in the second quarter was $67 million, and operating margin was 15% compared to last year's operating income of $87 million and 17.8% margin. 
Turning to electronic systems on Slide 8. Second quarter revenue was $382 million compared to prior year pro forma of $451 million. Higher revenue from the ramp in F-35 production was more than offset by lower electronic warfare revenue. Operating income in the second quarter was $69 million, and operating margin was 18.1% compared to last year's operating income of $78 million and 17.3% margin. 
Turning to Critical Networks on Slide 9. Second quarter revenue was $541 million compared to prior year pro forma of $672 million. Lower revenue and IT Services in CapRock's energy market was partially offset by higher FAA revenue, driven by NextGen modernization programs. Operating income in the second quarter was $71 million, and operating margin was 13.1% compared to last year's operating income of $83 million and 12.4% margin. 
So let me turn it back to Bill for the guidance discussion and a few wrapup comments.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Mick. So moving to Slides 10 and 11. Revenue guidance on an organic basis as revised from down 3% to 5% to now down 5% to 6%. We expect the impact of lower volume on earnings to be more than offset by the flow-through of the R&D tax credi
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Mick. So moving to Slides 10 and 11. Revenue guidance on an organic basis as revised from down 3% to 5% to now down 5% to 6%. We expect the impact of lower volume on earnings to be more than offset by the flow-through of the R&D tax credit and cost savings across the company. As a result, non-GAAP EPS guidance has been increased to a range of $5.70 to $5.80. And to remind you, non-GAAP includes intangible amortization from the Exelis acquisition of $133 million or about $0.70 per share. 
In Communication Systems, the expectations are unchanged. In Space and Intel, operating margin expectations have been revised to a range of 15% to 15.5%, primarily to reflect the higher mix of cost plus revenue and new program starts. In electronic systems, revenue expectations have been revised to a range of down 2% to 3% due to a few losses in electronic warfare pursuits combined with a lower-than-expected ramp of previous electronic warfare wins. In Critical Networks, revenue expectations have been revised to down about 14% due to further weakness in Government IT Services and CapRock's energy market. 
So to wrap up, as I said upfront, our top priorities are successfully integrating Exelis, delivering strong free cash flow, deleveraging our balance sheet and continuing to reshape the portfolio. And through the first half of the year, we're making good progress on all of them. So while we still face top line pressure in fiscal '16, integration and other cost-reduction actions are driving good earnings growth, and we expect this rising trend in earnings to continue into fiscal '17. 
And with that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the lines for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could give us some of the metrics you provided us in the past with respect to tactical backlog, tactical order backlog, book-to-bill and the respective pipelines, U.S. and foreign?
componenttext: Wondering if you could give us some of the metrics you provided us in the past with respect to tactical backlog, tactical order backlog, book-to-bill and the respective pipelines, U.S. and foreign?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's a lot of information. I think that's in here. Let me see if I could hit on some of the key things, and I'll provide you I think as much as I can on that. First thought, the -- on the book-to-bill, this is all legacy tactical radios, so go bac
componenttext: Okay, that's a lot of information. I think that's in here. Let me see if I could hit on some of the key things, and I'll provide you I think as much as I can on that. First thought, the -- on the book-to-bill, this is all legacy tactical radios, so go back to sort of how Harris define tactical radio. Our book-to-bill in the first half was up [ph] 0.97, so international was 0.99, as mentioned in my remarks, and DoD was a little bit less than that. A little bit softer in Q2, but we had a very strong Q1. Remember, it was about 1.3. Revenue, we believe came in about as expected in the quarter, a bit stronger in international, which as we said, up 10%, a little bit lower in the DoD. it's Flat overall in Q2 and up 3% in the first half, so I think overall, a pretty decent start. For the full year, we still state see revenue being flat to down low single digits. We still see DoD to be flat up slightly, and international be down slightly on a year-over-year basis. And it's really shaping up almost as we had expected where we initiated guidance 6 months ago: up, first half; down in the second half on a year-over-year basis. With 2 bigger tranches and to specific countries winding down, that makes for tougher comparisons in the back half. We still see sequentially the second half being up versus the first, with Europe and the Middle East both contributing pretty nicely. In fact, in this year, we think Europe is shaping up to be a record or near-record year for us, driven a lot by this ERI U.S. Government funding for Ukraine and the Baltics as well as a few other Central European, Eastern European countries. But we do see the impact of lower oil pricing that's shifting some of the priorities in some of the countries in the Middle East as well as some of the priorities of the U.S. government. So that's giving a little bit of more caution in the back half, but still we see second half up sequentially from the first. Now let me turn to the pipeline and just quickly cover that. In the international side, the pipeline is still very robust. It's now $2.9 billion. Last time, it was $2.4 billion. So it's come up as we brought in about a $600 million opportunity for Phase 3 modernization in Australia. We expect that the award at the end of fiscal '17, so that is now into our 12- to 18-month pipeline. The Middle East is still very solid. On a dollar basis, it's still about the same as it was before. On a percentage basis, down a little bit, now slightly under 50% because the size of the overall pipeline has increased, so still very, very broad. Again, Europe is strong. is holding [indiscernible] and we see Asia coming up pretty nicely, meaning because of Australia. So that's on the international front. On the DoD side the pipeline is at $890 million, so down slightly from where we were last time, about $925 million, so it was just under $900 million. The mix is still about the same, 60% Air Force, SOCOM, Marine Corps; and about 25% being Army in part modernization and part resets and other opportunities. So let me stop with that, Gautam, and see if I answer that question that you're trying to get at.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're definitely did. And I was wondering also, originally, when you announced the acquisition of Exelis, you laid out $1 billion free cash flow target a couple of years out. I was wondering if with the new synergy target and what have you, are you
componenttext: Yes, you're definitely did. And I was wondering also, originally, when you announced the acquisition of Exelis, you laid out $1 billion free cash flow target a couple of years out. I was wondering if with the new synergy target and what have you, are you still comfortable with that? Do you see upside to that? And if you could maybe bridge us from where we are today at $750 million of free cash to that $1 billion? What are the big puts and takes that get us there?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I think for this year, we're still feeling very comfortable at a free cash guidance around $750 million as we noted in our guidance, and that numerically hasn't changed. The words around that is numerically the same as we guided before to $75
componenttext: Well, first, I think for this year, we're still feeling very comfortable at a free cash guidance around $750 million as we noted in our guidance, and that numerically hasn't changed. The words around that is numerically the same as we guided before to $750 million. And without getting beyond '16 guidance, we do still see 3 or 4 years out of $1 billion of free cash flow. The drivers are as we expected before. We do see the higher run rate synergies impacting that free cash flows growing from $750 million. We see interest rate reductions, interest cost reductions coming down because we're paying down some debt. We do see continued working capital performance improvements over time. Recall, we're at, as Harris, last year fiscal '15, about 46  days working capital. Exelis was quite a bit higher than that. We came in at about 56 days at the end of Q2. So just as we get back to where Harris was before, we see another 10-plus-or-minus days of improvement of working capital at about $20 million per day. So we'll close some of that this year. But even we don't close all of that, it's still to be substantial increases in cash flow just simply from capital. Of course, we also see a little bit of capital spend efficiency over time as well. So those are the major elements. Again, we're still confident about $1 billion 3 to 4 years out.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the Middle East comments, you just made there on the international piece, Bill, could maybe just go back to that ultimately, first, I heard you make an incrementally positive comments and I thought I heard incrementally negative comment. And w
componenttext: In terms of the Middle East comments, you just made there on the international piece, Bill, could maybe just go back to that ultimately, first, I heard you make an incrementally positive comments and I thought I heard incrementally negative comment. And we hear a decent amount of concern out there on what might happen in that business for you because of the oil price, so you just can dig a little further into the trends? And if you're able to size how big that is as a percentage of your international business right now, that would be helpful.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been cautious over the last 2 or 3 quarters that the declining oil prices are impacting -- it seemingly puts some friction on the pace of awards that we're seeing in the Middle East. It doesn't impact the overall size of our international or o
componenttext: Well, we've been cautious over the last 2 or 3 quarters that the declining oil prices are impacting -- it seemingly puts some friction on the pace of awards that we're seeing in the Middle East. It doesn't impact the overall size of our international or our Middle East pipeline. We still see opportunities there to flow those opportunities to the pipeline or seeing a little bit more friction. And we now in Saudi, Saudi has been a significant opportunity for us, one of the big in our pipeline, like Iraq happens to be in others throughout the Middle East. There's 5 or 6 countries that make us the biggest of international -- Middle East part of our pipeline. And we do see in Saudi, in particular, where their focus on the war in Yemen and military purchases to support that, we're seeing some of the opportunities on the radio business slip a little bit to the right both in terms of Harris as well as what was legacy Exelis. So that has slipped a little bit to the right. But overall, do I think the opportunity in the Middle East still remains out there? The pipeline size is still very good and very robust, and we're very encouraged by the fact that there's strong U.S. Government support, FMS support for opportunities in the Middle East. And I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we talked about this last time. The ITEF funding, that flowed from the U.S. Government is flowing in and is helping us in Q2, and we do expect to see more opportunities into the future. GFY16, it was just about $700 million worth of ITEF funding, which is Counterterrorism Partnerships Fund, which includes amount for Syria, so $1.1 billion. So there's a lot of U.S. Government funding that does backstop our Middle East pipeline. So as I said in my remarks, we do see on a year-over-year basis, the second half and tactical to be down but sequentially up first half to second half.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The CapRock energy business 1.5 years ago was around -- about $400 million and down about 30%, so it's running this year just under $300 million on a reported basis for fiscal '16. We would expect by the time we hit Q4 to be a run rate similar around $250
componenttext: The CapRock energy business 1.5 years ago was around -- about $400 million and down about 30%, so it's running this year just under $300 million on a reported basis for fiscal '16. We would expect by the time we hit Q4 to be a run rate similar around $250 million, a little less than $250 million is the way that we're sizing it, so that's around $60 million, $65 million per quarter and will this year be a mid-single-digit margin business. By the fourth quarter, we're starting to kind of bump around breakeven based on the size of the business being where it has to be, which is why we've taken that the strong actions we've done to restructure, reposition that business.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

It looks like, by my Math, it was down on the order of 1/3 or so for the first half of the year. And I'm just wondering overall, is the pace of facilities consolidation? Do you think that's having a negative impact on Exelis revenue overall? It just looks like kind of everything is coming down on that acquisition sales.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pete, no, thank you. The business, we knew it would be down this year. It's a little bit weaker than we thought. It's down probably in the double digits now for the year. Early in the year when I was guiding to our original down 3 to 5, we're sizing and N
componenttext: Pete, no, thank you. The business, we knew it would be down this year. It's a little bit weaker than we thought. It's down probably in the double digits now for the year. Early in the year when I was guiding to our original down 3 to 5, we're sizing and NBCS to be down around 5% or 6% or sort of mid-single digits, and it's got a little bit worse than that. Keep in mind, the comp system business, 75% of that is international SINCGARS radios. Some of that goes into the Middle East, so they're also being impacted by Middle East. But we have contemplated being a weaker year. The night vision, broadly, is $150 million business. It's flattish versus last year. So we're holding serving night vision, the comp system business, and certainly, on a year-over-year basis is down a little bit worse than we had expected.  And I don't think the facility changed in Fort Wayne is having any impact whatsoever on any of this transition.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up on aerostructure divestiture. Are you to use the funds to repay debt or maybe offset dilution with share repurchases? I think you got about little over $1.5 billion debt coming due that's current debt right now, and I'm just wondering i
componenttext: Just one follow-up on aerostructure divestiture. Are you to use the funds to repay debt or maybe offset dilution with share repurchases? I think you got about little over $1.5 billion debt coming due that's current debt right now, and I'm just wondering if the plan is to pay all that off? Or how do you thinking all of that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our expectation is to use the proceeds from aerostructures to pay down debt is our expectation today, but we don't really see the divestiture of aerostructures to be all that material to our guidance for the year in terms of EPS. It's a couple of pen
componenttext: Yes, our expectation is to use the proceeds from aerostructures to pay down debt is our expectation today, but we don't really see the divestiture of aerostructures to be all that material to our guidance for the year in terms of EPS. It's a couple of pennies, but it's not material.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Seth Seifman with JPMorgan.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder we have the guidance for the segments for this year, but just the new segments, if you could talk maybe broadly and maybe just qualitatively at this point, but how do you think about margins progressing over time for each of the segments and wher
componenttext: I wonder we have the guidance for the segments for this year, but just the new segments, if you could talk maybe broadly and maybe just qualitatively at this point, but how do you think about margins progressing over time for each of the segments and where the targets are for this year relative to kind of what you might like to see?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you see what's happening in the margins in the guidance. We typically see quarter-to-quarter some fluctuations, Seth, and you saw -- you went through some of the charts some sequential deteriorations, some business have been up or down, CN w
componenttext: Well, I think you see what's happening in the margins in the guidance. We typically see quarter-to-quarter some fluctuations, Seth, and you saw -- you went through some of the charts some sequential deteriorations, some business have been up or down, CN was actually quite strong on a sequential and year-over-year basis because of mix. It was a lot of FAA work that's going in there offsetting decline in services as well as in CapRock. Things are moving around a little bit. But we'll see margins continuing to improve going out into next year simply based on better volume and also the integration savings are going to continue to roll through, and we keep working hard to drive our normal OpEx agenda. So we expect that we'll see margins improving. Right now, I think we're pretty strong this year in CS. We were guiding to 29.5 to 30.5 so we're holding on that. And we do expect based on mix and the trends we're seeing in the business that we could be towards the higher end of that. The SIS business is a government contracting business. While it's a little bit weaker in terms of margin than we expect it before, it's pretty solid 15, 15.5. So I think that's very, very strong ES at 18% to 19% is a very strong margin. That will be impacted over time by some changes in the mix of the programs as we bring on newer programs and move off  of legacy ones, so we'll see some of the integration savings offset some of the mix. In CN, we're just battling right now what's happening in the CapRock business and services. The FAA work in international opportunities for mission networks or FAA-like opportunities, I think, are going to help us there. So I wouldn't want to get too far out of fiscal '16 in terms of margin guidance here, Seth, but that's where we stand right now for within the year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And then maybe just as a follow-up, I'm not sure we've spoken since the budget deal came out. It's look like there might be some puts and takes for particular program, so maybe just your thoughts on that and on what we expect to hear
componenttext: That's helpful color. And then maybe just as a follow-up, I'm not sure we've spoken since the budget deal came out. It's look like there might be some puts and takes for particular program, so maybe just your thoughts on that and on what we expect to hear in the coming weeks?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I had a crystal ball with what we're going to announce in the next week, but I really can't comment on that. But I think from a fiscal '16 basis, like others in the industry have been expressing, the 2-year deal feels pretty good. It's good for Harr
componenttext: Well, I had a crystal ball with what we're going to announce in the next week, but I really can't comment on that. But I think from a fiscal '16 basis, like others in the industry have been expressing, the 2-year deal feels pretty good. It's good for Harris, it's good for the industry. We see what's happening in the DoD base budget this year and next year, so it's on an upswing at least a little bit and which I think is very positive. Now for Harris, in particular, I think we feel very good about our programs. The tactical radio lines that we typically pull from are well supported. Army modernization, we think is adequately covered. The FAA looks really good. The NextGen programs were well-funded in fiscal '16. We were pleased to see funding for GPS3, which is an important Exelis program on SV9 and 10. Weather programs were well supported, and I'm glad that you see the recent award come through very recently on the Chris payloads for GPS3 and 4. F-35, we got a pretty large content per ship set. Again, we're seeing that ramp. That was well supported. In addition, the F-18 aircraft into the budget. There were 7 or 8 aircraft. It was also good because Exelis is an EW product line for the F-18. And again, finally, OCO, we feel good about because of the amounts that are in there, which support some of the international FMS opportunities that we're going after in our tactical business. So overall, Seth, I think we feel pretty good about where the budget came out.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Stallard with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Stallard with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that some of your products and service areas have continued to go through some revenue pressures, but I was wondering, in particular, IT Services, for example. I was wondering your conversations with customers and bookings over the last quar
componenttext: You mentioned that some of your products and service areas have continued to go through some revenue pressures, but I was wondering, in particular, IT Services, for example. I was wondering your conversations with customers and bookings over the last quarter have indicated that it's getting less bad and that we can see a trough in these areas?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: On IT Services, we are -- first of all, it was weaker than we thought it would be in the quarter. And I think as we've been talking about probably for the last 3 or 4 quarters, we've been impacted by couple of sizable program roll-offs. We still see the o
componenttext: On IT Services, we are -- first of all, it was weaker than we thought it would be in the quarter. And I think as we've been talking about probably for the last 3 or 4 quarters, we've been impacted by couple of sizable program roll-offs. We still see the overall procurement environment being relatively weak. We adjusted powerful your expectations for IT Services. We came into the year thinking we'd be down mid-teens, and it's now down probably in the 23%, 25% range over the course of the year. But we do see, at least sequentially, it's stabilizing quarter-to-quarter going through the back end of fiscal '16. Our book-to-bill in Q2 in the first half was reasonably good. It was over 1, of course, on a lower revenue environment, but the book-to-bill was pretty good, which again gets us encouraged that we can support some stability in the back half. We also have incumbent positions on some legacy programs that as the roll-off start to ease, I think we'll see more stability in the back half. So for the pipeline that we have, we've got a very large pipeline of opportunities that we're chasing. It's actually come up a couple of billion from the beginning of the year. It's something like $24 billion now. We have, within Harris, we've got to make sure that we improve our win rate. Our win rate is a little bit below what our target happens to be. We typically win in the 23%, 25%. It should be 30% or more, so we're not winning quite as much as we need to be. A lot of that is really around our frontline execution and our process execution, and we're getting that fixed. So I do think rather part of it this is a slow environment and part of it is what we need to do to improve our own win rate internally within the company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And the maybe the second question, you mentioned Manpack and the DoD's timetable to get this done in Q1. If you really stick to that assuming you win something, when could the revenues from these awards start to flow through?
componenttext: Right. And the maybe the second question, you mentioned Manpack and the DoD's timetable to get this done in Q1. If you really stick to that assuming you win something, when could the revenues from these awards start to flow through?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're not expecting revenue opportunities to really hit us till really going into fiscal '18. I mean, it'll be free production. If they stick to the current schedule, I believe it's in the middle of 2017, calendar '17, so around June, which really means m
componenttext: We're not expecting revenue opportunities to really hit us till really going into fiscal '18. I mean, it'll be free production. If they stick to the current schedule, I believe it's in the middle of 2017, calendar '17, so around June, which really means more significant revenue would impact our fiscal '18 not '17.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just Bill, I'm wondering kind of hit on the comments you made about the aerostructures divestitures and the dispassionate approach you mentioned in your prepared remarks on the portfolio. I know you're probably right on the about the time of the year wher
componenttext: Just Bill, I'm wondering kind of hit on the comments you made about the aerostructures divestitures and the dispassionate approach you mentioned in your prepared remarks on the portfolio. I know you're probably right on the about the time of the year where you're putting it a for strategic plan as a combined company, and sort of wondering what kind of qualify as a strategic and not strategic at this point? Maybe just give us an update on how you think about what the various hurdles are to make a business strategically value -- valuable to what you want Harris to look like with Exelis and the combined entity?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a very good question, Carter, and you're right, we are getting into our strategic planning process and that will kind of inform a little bit more on what sort of portfolio we want over the long term. And so I rarely comment about any specific busines
componenttext: It's a very good question, Carter, and you're right, we are getting into our strategic planning process and that will kind of inform a little bit more on what sort of portfolio we want over the long term. And so I rarely comment about any specific business, but at the end of the day, a couple of things I would share with you. One, we are a technology-based company. We invest in new product development, and we want to use technology to differentiate offerings in the marketplace. So one of the key things that I look for are the things that the business is that we want to be in should be able to be differentiated by providing some technology. We are also a mission-critical communication defense electronics-type company. So for the aerostructures business, we've got these large composite skins and large factories and lot of capital intensity. It really didn't necessarily fit with the rest of what we look like. So I think that one, as we came into the year, we're looking hard which businesses should management focus its time and attention on, on a continuum of businesses that go from very, very strategic like tactical radios on the far left to may be less strategic on the far right being aerostructures. Other businesses sit in the middle, and I'm using the criteria that I just described to assess which ones we should keep and which we should and should not. At the end of the day, does it fit strategically? Is it more valuable to us versus to somebody else? We look at performance of the company, performance of the business. All of those factors come into play in determining which ones we should keep and which ones we should not.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you have a bias either government versus commercially leaning at this point, or it's agnostic to that?
componenttext: Do you have a bias either government versus commercially leaning at this point, or it's agnostic to that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're pretty agnostic. It's more about where -- what businesses should we be in that we can bring some value to end customers, where we can apply technology, where we can differentiate our offering, where we can gain market share through differentiated of
componenttext: We're pretty agnostic. It's more about where -- what businesses should we be in that we can bring some value to end customers, where we can apply technology, where we can differentiate our offering, where we can gain market share through differentiated offerings. All of those developed -- generate a very satisfactory return on investment in those businesses. Those are the things that we're looking at, and they could be commercial or government. We see a big part of our business today is on the government side. We're very good at that, but that doesn't really drive the decision at the moment.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a couple of final clarifications. On the space and Intel margin revision, I wonder if you could give us some detail on what drove that since the revenue basis is unchanged. And just some clarification on what you meant by bandwidth consoli
componenttext: Great. And just a couple of final clarifications. On the space and Intel margin revision, I wonder if you could give us some detail on what drove that since the revenue basis is unchanged. And just some clarification on what you meant by bandwidth consolidation at CapRock and what that was meant to accomplish?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In space and Intel -- thank you, Carter, on the space and Intel side, really it's just a shifting mix of what's in the business, slightly more cost plus and fixed-price contracts. And we're seeing some of the new starts and new wins that space and Intel a
componenttext: In space and Intel -- thank you, Carter, on the space and Intel side, really it's just a shifting mix of what's in the business, slightly more cost plus and fixed-price contracts. And we're seeing some of the new starts and new wins that space and Intel are getting in coming out at slightly lower margin, so we just adjust it down to reflect that. There's nothing structural in that business that's causing it. On the CapRock side, look, it's pretty remarkable the amount of bandwidth that's being consumed by the cruise industry and our expectation for whether that's going to grow over time. It is growing very, very quickly. And with a very significant change in the supply structure of bandwidth, satellite bandwidth, we're able to use that leverage to both negotiate better deals, better pricing and globally consistent pricing, so we don't have for different types of satellites, for different customers in different regions very different pricing. We're looking for pricing uniformity, and it helps run our business a little more efficiently and effectively. And that's what we're heading on the bandwidth deal. So thank you for those questions, Carter.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Josh Sullivan from CRT.
componenttext: Our next question is from Josh Sullivan from CRT.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: With public potentially turning the corner here, can you provide a little color on Harris' position with the first net RFP? Are you teaming with anybody? Does it matter for Harris anybody who wins? Just a little color on that RFP and how Harris is positio
componenttext: With public potentially turning the corner here, can you provide a little color on Harris' position with the first net RFP? Are you teaming with anybody? Does it matter for Harris anybody who wins? Just a little color on that RFP and how Harris is positioned.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Josh. Well, the RFP is out, which is good. We've been tracking this for several years. i think it's good news that it's out. We've met with the FirstNet board a couple of different times, and we're pleased to see it out there. There's a p
componenttext: Well, thank you, Josh. Well, the RFP is out, which is good. We've been tracking this for several years. i think it's good news that it's out. We've met with the FirstNet board a couple of different times, and we're pleased to see it out there. There's a process that they laid out. I think it's a little bit on the aggressive side. There's questions and capability assessments that are due coming up her in February and March. Bids are due on, I think, the 29 of April. They don't get extended. My expectation is what comes out in the RFP is a June award, a preliminary in June. And then it goes to this day consultation period, for 90 days when the state have an opportunity to opt-in or opt-out. And then, after which, whoever is the preliminary award winner would resubmit a new bid and with the final award by November of '16. So that to me it's a pretty aggressive time line. I think the RFP, Josh, feels like it's geared more towards commercial carriers as primes. Just by the way, it's written in some of the requirements in the RFP. We are, as Harris is still assessing the role that we're going to play since it's a live competitive procurement, I don't think you want to talk more about that. But we're in the middle of assessing the way that which we want to participate in what could be very interesting long-term opportunity that transforms the Public Safety networks in North America.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Quilty with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Quilty with Raymond James.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question, it looks like GPS OCX contract may come up for rebid. Can you talk about how that might impact you either positive or negative?
componenttext: Question, it looks like GPS OCX contract may come up for rebid. Can you talk about how that might impact you either positive or negative?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're watching it very carefully, Chris. We're working diligently to support our prime customer, which is Raytheon. Raytheon is the prime on OCX. And I think you've read a lot in the press about some of the challenges in that program, really around
componenttext: Well, we're watching it very carefully, Chris. We're working diligently to support our prime customer, which is Raytheon. Raytheon is the prime on OCX. And I think you've read a lot in the press about some of the challenges in that program, really around cybersecurity protections, which are causing the development time frame to go quite long. And it's gotten a lot of attention on the hill with General Hayden, with Secretary James, a lot of people that are focused on this as the team at Raytheon, and we're working diligently to support Raytheon in their program and getting them back on schedule, at least holding to the schedule they've articulated. Really, not much more to say at this point on that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you feel Harris' performance on that contract has been up to par?
componenttext: And do you feel Harris' performance on that contract has been up to par?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a legacy Exelis program. We're both on the payload for GPS3, so on the payload side as well as the ground side supporting Raytheon. And our understanding is, our team has performed well. We bring good systems engineering capability, and I think we pe
componenttext: It's a legacy Exelis program. We're both on the payload for GPS3, so on the payload side as well as the ground side supporting Raytheon. And our understanding is, our team has performed well. We bring good systems engineering capability, and I think we performed well to our customer, but I don't think I would suggest -- say more than that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think Exelis has also had some issues on the GPS payload side. Where do you stand in terms of resolving those issues?
componenttext: And I think Exelis has also had some issues on the GPS payload side. Where do you stand in terms of resolving those issues?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this was a -- first of all, they're very complicated payload. It's a very difficult one, and the requirements were quite stringent. Maybe they weren't fully understood many years ago when Exelis won it. It was very late. It got a lot of attention. Un
componenttext: Yes, this was a -- first of all, they're very complicated payload. It's a very difficult one, and the requirements were quite stringent. Maybe they weren't fully understood many years ago when Exelis won it. It was very late. It got a lot of attention. Under Exelis, they deployed a very good team at it just towards the end when we were buying the company. We have also deployed experts into the Clifton facility, half a dozen or dozen very good people on manufacturing operations, design engineering, a lot of different things. And there's been I think very good progress here made over the last 6 to 9 months. And over the holiday, just before the holidays, the very first space [indiscernible] with our payload came out of thermal vac early with very, very good performance. And it was, I think it's a fantastic accomplishment by Lockheed, by our team, by the Air Force and we're all very, very proud of that. And I think that puts us on a really good trajectory on GPS3 on the space side. And that gives us more confidence with Lockheed that, that SV9 and 10 should get awarded sometime this fiscal year. So I think our performance has improved pretty much here, Chris.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. And with that last question, Bill has a few wrapup commons, and then we'll close down the call.
componenttext: Thank you, Chris. And with that last question, Bill has a few wrapup commons, and then we'll close down the call.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, thank you, Pam. And before we end the call, I want to take this opportunity to let you know that Nic Lopez has decided to leave Harris for personal reasons to pursue new opportunities outside the company. As you know, these last 2 years with M
componenttext: Okay, well, thank you, Pam. And before we end the call, I want to take this opportunity to let you know that Nic Lopez has decided to leave Harris for personal reasons to pursue new opportunities outside the company. As you know, these last 2 years with Mick as CFO have been truly transformative for Harris with signing, the closing, the financing of the largest acquisition in our company's history. And I want to thank Mick for his leadership and his many contributions to Harris over the last 2 years Mick, so thank you for that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. I really appreciate your kind words.
componenttext: Thank you, Bill. I really appreciate your kind words.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So succeeding Mick will be Raul guy. Raul has led our finance integration teams since March of 2015. Raul has a diverse finance background with experience in both commercial and aerospace industries, including Executive readership roles at both at Aetna a
componenttext: So succeeding Mick will be Raul guy. Raul has led our finance integration teams since March of 2015. Raul has a diverse finance background with experience in both commercial and aerospace industries, including Executive readership roles at both at Aetna as well as United Technologies. The press release with more details will be issued momentarily. Please join me in wishing Mick well in his future endeavors and also welcoming Raul to Harris as our new Chief Financial Officer. So as usual, Pam will be available throughout the day to address any additional questions that you might have. And I want to thank you again for joining our call today, so thank you.
