headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, we're not going to provide today any guidance. We'll come to that in early August. But I think when you talk about communications, your question seems more direct towards the tactical side, which as we know has been more of the important
componenttext: Well, first off, we're not going to provide today any guidance. We'll come to that in early August. But I think when you talk about communications, your question seems more direct towards the tactical side, which as we know has been more of the important earnings driver. So we're not going to provide some guidance today, but there's several things that are on our radar screen that we'd like to see happen in the near term that it'll help some of the guidance will provide in early August. In the DOD side, both Nuos [ph] and the MNVR radio, the mid-tier radio, together wil contribute to higher earnings, higher revenue in fiscal '17. Nuos which did solid quarter is we expect to receive certifications on that this summer, NASA certification. We've already demonstrated on-air performance for both the voice and data. It's well supported, funds are allocated and it's a very strong and compelling business case, so we're very proud that's going to happen over the next several months. On the mid-Tier side, on the MNVR, that will be in tens of millions of dollars, it's well supported in the President's budget request as well as in the NDAA that just came out. The network assessment is going on as we speak. And we expect a production award towards the end of government fiscal year '16, so around September timeframe. I think on the international side which is become a bigger part of our business and it's a very large pipeline, we're looking at what's occurring in Eastern Europe and the Ukraine where we've very, very strong in fiscal '16. We need that to continue. We need to see the opportunities that we've seen very well in Iraq in fiscal '16. We expect that to continue at the same level as we see in '16. And again, opportunities in Iraw to us, as we speak today, seem to be well supported. One of the opportunities in the international that slipped out of fiscal '16 into '17 is in Iraq, but it's well funded. We think that that's going to happen in the '17. There's another country in the Middle East we can't name where an opportunity did slip out and we expect that to happen in early '17 as well. And then finally, in Central Asia, meaning specifically Afghanistan, we've had a very strong year this year. Opportunities there seem well supported. And we do expect Afghanistan and, more broadly, Central Asia to be a strong contributor to revenue into next year. Now outside the Tactical Communication, we have a broader business outside of legacy tactical, we have a broader communications business, including Exelis, the radio business from Exelis, which is mostly international. We've been tracking an opportunity in Saudi Arabia for quite some time. It's about $40 million, $50 million in size for radio for vehicles. It's been hung up in the Saudi Royal Court for a number of months and we need that to break free as we get into '17 as well. So maybe Pete, just a little bit of shape and color around what we expect going to next year.

componenttext: Yes, Gautham. In the course of Q4, we expect to end the year with funded backlog in Tactical in line with Q3 or slightly up. So we do expect to see some decent awards in Q4 about at the level of revenue. So we don't see another step down in backlog at this point, but in line with where we are in Q3. We're not anticipating or providing any guidance on Q1 into '17. Although we are watching very carefully the network assessment. The funding for MNVR is in the '16 budget. There's money allocated in the '17 PBR. It seems to be protected in the NDA that came out of at about $20 million, $25 million, and we do anticipate a production award occurring in September timeframe. That could have -- that can drive revenue beyond that, may not be in Q1, but we do think that that's going to end up occurring as we get into '17.

componenttext: Yes, it's in the tens of millions of dollars that slipped beyond Q4 into Q1, Q2. It's possible we received the order late this quarter. It more likely is in Q1 of our fiscal '17. As I said in my prepared remarks, the business case on that is really very, very compelling. And we've demonstrated on performance of the 117G with MUOS already. And I think it's a great opportunity for us and we're confident it's going to go forward. It may not happen this quarter.

componenttext: Yes. It really comes into 3 specific opportunities. The funding for that opportunity has been reprioritized, but the customer's working with us on a number of other projects which we believe will be funded in the first half of our fiscal '17. So it's relatively isolated to 3 different specific opportunities that generally just moved our of the quarter.

componenttext: Well, we think we've got a very, very strong and compelling offering. We've been working on it for a number of years. We have a very strong, very high share today in the Manpack market within the U.S. DOD. And we've developed, I think, a very good radio in a very large factory where it got tremendous scale. That through the R&D investments, we're able to continue to bring features and functionality of the radio scale make sure we're competitive on this cost side. So we think we've got a very, very strong offering for the Manpack.

componenttext: Good morning. This is Rahul. So I think we've said that will be about $2 billion in the first 3 years. So we're tracking to that. componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to address maybe a strategic question. You talked about continuing to optimize the business portfolio. Clearly, the sale of Aerostructures business was spectacular outcome. But optimize means lots of different things. So could you elaborate on th
componenttext: I wanted to address maybe a strategic question. You talked about continuing to optimize the business portfolio. Clearly, the sale of Aerostructures business was spectacular outcome. But optimize means lots of different things. So could you elaborate on that please?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we feel very good about where we ended on the Aerostructures business and completing the sale in early April. It's on top of what we did last year on the Commercial Healthcare business and before that, Broadcast. So I think we've been that pretty thi
componenttext: Yes, we feel very good about where we ended on the Aerostructures business and completing the sale in early April. It's on top of what we did last year on the Commercial Healthcare business and before that, Broadcast. So I think we've been that pretty this passionate, pretty aggressive and looking at what is in our portfolio, what strategically fits, what's a better value to Harris versus to an outside party. We also look at the performance of the underlying business. That's an important factor. But, Howard, as I step back, we are at the heart, a technology-based company, really defense electronics, mission critical communications and we want to be in businesses where technology is a discriminator, add some competitive advantage. We spend quite a bit on [indiscernible] 4% is well above our peers, 4% of our revenue. We have about 40% of our population are engineers, are scientists and we want to be in businesses where technology can allow us to win. And that's a key factor at how we evaluate the portfolio. We've been, again, aggressive in doing something with Aerostructures and we continue to look at what's in our base broader business that we have today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a lot of sense. And then just to build on that. Can you talk -- we can see the cost synergies from Exelis. Can you talk about a little bit on the sales synergies? Or where the organization is able to go to market with a package that can somehow
componenttext: That makes a lot of sense. And then just to build on that. Can you talk -- we can see the cost synergies from Exelis. Can you talk about a little bit on the sales synergies? Or where the organization is able to go to market with a package that can somehow accelerate some growth? Will you give -- just to finish on that, you did a nice job, I think, of outlining what you're doing in radios, but the other markets are very large as well in report.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our focus has been, Howard, really around the cost take out. And we've done, I think, a very good job. We got out of it very quickly. And we still feel good about hitting our run rate savings as we exit '17 and at 140, 150 net range, which is more ag
componenttext: Yes. Our focus has been, Howard, really around the cost take out. And we've done, I think, a very good job. We got out of it very quickly. And we still feel good about hitting our run rate savings as we exit '17 and at 140, 150 net range, which is more aggressive than we thought. We're closing about 50% of our floor space and that's tracking very, very well. So that has been our #1 focus. And that's how we justify the acquisition, it was really on cost take out. On the revenue side, yes, we've got our teams really focused on this, Dana Mehner, who's been at Harris for more than 30 years, really built our Tactical Radio business into what it is today, has now taken on a role as head a global business development, really with an eye towards how do we grow in major markets around the world where the opportunities might be a little bit outside of the horizon or between businesses or might involve bringing together, strapping together, some technology from Exelis with Harris. And this focus is really on that. And it's across as a gambit, it's across technology, across platform, across geographies or channels to market. And all those things, we're starting to see some opportunities. And as we get beyond this year and start to shape '17, we'll talk a bit more about where they start to -- where we're starting to see those opportunities come to fruition. What I'd rather do is talk about the one that we are actually achieving as we achieve them as opposed to speculating about where they might be. One last point on this, Howard, because I think it's a very important and I want to make sure investors don't miss this. It's not just about applying common technologies going after channels. The part of what we're doing in driving operational excellence and integration into across Exelis is improving program performance. This is very important. The best way to grow our business is performing well on what you're doing today. And in the note that -- in Rahul's prepared remarks, he talked about the sensor program. The sensor program is being recompleted because the performance was up with Air Force and through a lot of work, the on-time delivery of the program has improved dramatically. And now we're starting to get awards back on sensor and the competition has been canceled going to one of the pieces of sensor because of the improved performance. So I feel if we just keep focused on performance and executing very, very well, that will help us grow our business into the future as well.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then one last item. You've got, again, sort of focused on the top line a little bit. You've got an enormous amount of data you provide to the FAA and some of that can be remarketed and sold in a value-added manner. How far along are you with that?
componenttext: And then one last item. You've got, again, sort of focused on the top line a little bit. You've got an enormous amount of data you provide to the FAA and some of that can be remarketed and sold in a value-added manner. How far along are you with that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our focus right now with the FAA is executing on NextGen programs. And FAA today is probably our largest customer. We're on 4 of 5 NexGen programs and, of course,  we've got the FTI, the telecommunication infrastructure that we're working on. But th
componenttext: Well, our focus right now with the FAA is executing on NextGen programs. And FAA today is probably our largest customer. We're on 4 of 5 NexGen programs and, of course,  we've got the FTI, the telecommunication infrastructure that we're working on. But through Exelis, they have the ADS-B network more, than 640 radio towers operating very well long-term contract with the FAA. Very strong position. And they have unique access to data. And that data can be used in other forms for other uses, including supporting the integration of UAVs into the North American air traffic control system. That is a key part of our strategy. That's an opportunity that's likely be on the next couple of 3-year planning horizon. But clearly, through both technology partnerships and legislation, all of which need to be worked on today to make sure we've got a strong position there over time. So Howard, that is an important focus of ours and as we get clear around what particular strategies that will share that more with investors. That's a little bit beyond the planning horizon.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of our Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe the horse isn't quite dead yet, so I'll beat it again. So I want to talk tactical really quickly. And I know you're not ready to provide '17 guidance, but you talked about several of these opportunities which clearly layer in later in next fiscal ye
componenttext: Maybe the horse isn't quite dead yet, so I'll beat it again. So I want to talk tactical really quickly. And I know you're not ready to provide '17 guidance, but you talked about several of these opportunities which clearly layer in later in next fiscal year and beyond. And you've made a comment in your prepared remarks, in the closing remarks, about sort of short-term movements in revenue. But when you look at that business on a long-term trend line basis, is it your expectation that, that trend line is upward sloping when we look at over the next 2, 3, 5 years because of all the opportunities that we've been looking at and you've executed on in recent years?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question, Carter. Clearly, on the DOD side, I think the answer is yes. It's clearly on an upward slope. And I think as I went into some detail on the progress that we won on the DOD side and the fact that even in the President's budget
componenttext: I think it's a good question, Carter. Clearly, on the DOD side, I think the answer is yes. It's clearly on an upward slope. And I think as I went into some detail on the progress that we won on the DOD side and the fact that even in the President's budget, they're well supported in the DoD, they're were supported, the procurement of going forward at a reasonable pace. I feel very confident that the DoD business will be a growth driver for us, certainly as we get into the '18 and beyond. '17 is a little bit too soon to call. I do see it coming off the bottom in '16 into '17, but I think '18 is really the growth year. And I think it really relates to the flow in from some of these modernization programs where we were very, very well-positioned including in SOCOM. So the DoD, I think, clearly is a growth driver. On the international side, we've seen fantastic growth over the last few years. We've seen a little bit of softness this year. The pipeline is still very robust. We are still well positioned. Competitively, we are very strong. Where we are going out to compete, we win almost all the places that we are competing in around the world where we have a position. I think the opportunity in Australia where we become the preferred supplier for a very large contract would include systems and products is an important part of our strategy because, too, increased the size of the addressable market we're going after in international in order to group growth in an international base over time. But I do see on the DOD side, yes, that, that will be a longer-term growth market for us.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And on a couple of others. Just looking at the bookings trend and the revenue trend at CapRock. Does that business looks like it's bottomed now from your perspective?
componenttext: Okay, great. And on a couple of others. Just looking at the bookings trend and the revenue trend at CapRock. Does that business looks like it's bottomed now from your perspective?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the good news, Carter, is that we haven't adjusted in our outlook for '16. We haven't changed it based on what's going on in the CapRock business. The energy business is still under a lot of pressure and the oil price have recovered a little
componenttext: Well, I think the good news, Carter, is that we haven't adjusted in our outlook for '16. We haven't changed it based on what's going on in the CapRock business. The energy business is still under a lot of pressure and the oil price have recovered a little bit, but still well down. A lot of the energy majors are reporting some pretty terrible numbers right now. For the year, we still expect CapRock Energy to be down about 25%. We were down in the 20% range-ish in the first half. They'll be worse than that obviously in the second half. As we get into Q4, we see the revenue in Q4 on CapRock Energy to be on the order of about $60 million in the quarter. So if you just annualize that, you're sort around $240 million for the year as we exit fiscal '16 and for perspective in fiscal '16 overall, revenue caprock energy was around to $90 million. So the math would imply that we'll see a little bit of another downturn on an annual basis in '17 over '16. '16 again is down about 25% from fiscal '15. So we are seeing another step down as we get into next year. But it's not different than what we described last time and did -- and built into our guidance for this year. I guess, as you saw the CM margins, we're down little bit sequentially. We did lose money in energy in Q3, but we've done quite a bit the restructuring as we laid out to investors back in February. And we do expect the energy business to go back to profitability in Q4 and be less of a profit driver as we get into fiscal '17.

componenttext: Yes, exactly.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: And then one final one. Just a clarification. The increase in the synergies clearly benefits the fourth quarter this year. But does that imply any change to the run rate synergy target on Exelis that you laid out before? Or this is just faster capture?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's faster capture. We still expect to be at 140, 150 net -- $140 million to $150 million net of what we give back to the government as we exit fiscal '17. So it's really just a faster capture this year, $80 million, $85 million. We see next year, in yea
componenttext: It's faster capture. We still expect to be at 140, 150 net -- $140 million to $150 million net of what we give back to the government as we exit fiscal '17. So it's really just a faster capture this year, $80 million, $85 million. We see next year, in year fiscal '17, integration savings or synergy savings in the $130 million to $135 million range, Carter. So that implies an extra $50 million in that in-year '17 from '16.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize in advance for asking another 2017 question, but it's not in terms of numbers but just very broadly. Outside of communications, when we think about the DoD budget and investment account outlays should be up pretty nicely in government fiscal '
componenttext: I apologize in advance for asking another 2017 question, but it's not in terms of numbers but just very broadly. Outside of communications, when we think about the DoD budget and investment account outlays should be up pretty nicely in government fiscal '17. When we think about space and electronics, let's say, Critical Networks putting Caprock aside, with DoD investment account outlays growing nicely, is there any reason to expect that any of those segments won't grow?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we see very good trends through the year in our Space business as well as in the Electronic Systems business. And what's kind of encouraging to be through the year here in Space and pretty good backlog growth, pretty good book-to-bill through the ye
componenttext: Well, we see very good trends through the year in our Space business as well as in the Electronic Systems business. And what's kind of encouraging to be through the year here in Space and pretty good backlog growth, pretty good book-to-bill through the year, same thing on the Electronic Systems business.  It's good to see Electronic Warfare to be pretty strong, it turns out, over the course of the year and ending couple of hundred million dollars higher in backlog, at least that bodes well for not in those step down as we get into the '17. But yes, the budgets look pretty good. There's still a long way to go between where we are today in appropriations bills. But we feel pretty good about the overall outlook. The only cautionary points I would give is on Caprock. We do see, again, another step down as we get into '17 just based on where the exit rate happens to be. In our mission sustained business, which was down this year in the 20%, 22%, 23% range, mainly because of a couple program rollouts. We've got some work to do there to make sure that we hold that business as we going to next year. It's a very, very competitive landscape. We have about 1/3 of that business. It's up for recompete. As we go into next year, the mission sustained services business. And we've got to do deliver work to make sure that we went on those recompete, manning management team are well focused on today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe as a follow-up on cash flow. You maintained the free cash flow guidance for the year but the CapEx guidance came down. I was wondering if you can talk about the driver there. I mean, was it basically that the uppers in the EPS guidance were kind
componenttext: And maybe as a follow-up on cash flow. You maintained the free cash flow guidance for the year but the CapEx guidance came down. I was wondering if you can talk about the driver there. I mean, was it basically that the uppers in the EPS guidance were kind of noncash and versus the decline in the communications revenue. And then you still got a pretty big jump in the CapEx in Q4 and what specifically is driving that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, you're right. I mean, there's no change to our fiscal '16 guidance on cash flow. Reduction CapEx is basically offsetting the change in earnings. So that's where -- that's kind of the math we're doing. So we need to get the working capital improvem
componenttext: So yes, you're right. I mean, there's no change to our fiscal '16 guidance on cash flow. Reduction CapEx is basically offsetting the change in earnings. So that's where -- that's kind of the math we're doing. So we need to get the working capital improvement in the fourth quarter to get to our full year number. But historically, 50% of our cash flow for the year has come into the fourth quarter. And this year, we're expecting steadily less than that. So we feel good about that. I mean we have some projects going on -- the timing of CapEx the first from quarter-to-quarter. And they're just variability even the quarter. So we had some projects going on that need some step up in CapEx, but we've calibrated that outlook for the year. And we feel will be close to that number that we've guided to.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we feel pretty good, SEthernet, about the progress we've made over last several years and just making ourself a little more capital efficient and includes the approval thresholds in the company. On a pro forma basis, couple of years ago, the companie
componenttext: Yes, we feel pretty good, SEthernet, about the progress we've made over last several years and just making ourself a little more capital efficient and includes the approval thresholds in the company. On a pro forma basis, couple of years ago, the companies together would have been around $260 million, $270 million or in a range of 3% of sales, this year will be about 2.3%. We still see some opportunities to continue to be a little more judicious on capital spending going forward. So we feel pretty good about where we stand so far this year in capital.

componenttext: To just a follow-up on Australia and your the focus on systems. Can you give us an idea of what you end up bundling in, in the system sell in addition to radios? And what kind of a revenue multiplier or, I mean, does it increase the size of the potential order by 10% or 15% or double it?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Well, we would include the radios, we'll also include a lot of antenna systems as the battle management systems software systems. There's a variety of other things that we packaged in to a systems offering, to customer. Every end market is going to be a little bit different. We've had several hundred million dollars with a system opportunities being booked and sold in other markets in the past. If I remember right, on those markets, because I do want to talk specifically about Australia. It's probably in the order of around maybe 2 to 1. So 2 parts of the non-radios to 1 part radios. In other words, about 1/3 of the opportunity would be radios or thereabouts and the 2/3 will be other things you package around that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: And when you look at your opportunity pipeline down the road broadly, what percent of those international opportunities might you convert to more of a systems versus a traditional radio sales?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. That's something we've been working on for quite some time in the U.S. The U.S. Military tends to do their own systems integration. They manage each of the suppliers and the components and integrated together. And we tested to w
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. That's something we've been working on for quite some time in the U.S. The U.S. Military tends to do their own systems integration. They manage each of the suppliers and the components and integrated together. And we tested to what we have seated down today in this network evaluations, in these NIEs. On the international side, more customers are moving towards buying an installed solution, integrated solution. And that's, I think, a good trend and is heading in our direction. We feel very good that the radio itself is very, very competitive and provides a key source of value. We think we can broaden that and bring other partners on to our team. In fact, that's exactly what we've been able to do in Australia. So a very important large global players are on the Harris team in Australia, providing components to us. And what that does is you not just provide a radio but software and other components around that. It does continue to build more stickiness into that end customer coming back to Harris Corporation over time. So we feel very good about the trajectory we happen to be on in the systems and integrated solution side internationally.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And who would be our big competitors that are adopting the same approach?
componenttext: And who would be our big competitors that are adopting the same approach?

componenttext: Well, I don't want to get into the competitor mix because some of the competitors have found their way onto our team in Australia and it really varies by market. But I would just say that we've got a lineup of very good suppliers, good partners with us in Australia. And again, we go compete against different people in different markets.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a clarification on the MUOS. Is that a one-time revenue opportunity on the software upgrade or is there any kind of tail?
componenttext: Okay. And a clarification on the MUOS. Is that a one-time revenue opportunity on the software upgrade or is there any kind of tail?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's going to be -- we've been investing quite a bit of into developing the ability to easily port this MUOS waveform to 117J. It sounds more simple to explain than it really was. That was quite a bit of magic to make this happen and not require
componenttext: Well, there's going to be -- we've been investing quite a bit of into developing the ability to easily port this MUOS waveform to 117J. It sounds more simple to explain than it really was. That was quite a bit of magic to make this happen and not require any sort of firmware, hardware change out for these radios, which I think is actually amazing. Amazing what the team has done. And what we are now doing is working with our service partners to provide them software licenses that would allow them to, once they buy the license, to then download that software into their radios, into the 117Gs. As that MUOS waveform is changed or advanced over time, there may be opportunities for that to kind of get readvanced or other licenses or other opportunities, revenue opportunities to occur. But we see that over time, this is -- this is a pretty substantial opportunity. And I think as each service picks it up, will drive some revenue event for us on MUOS.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a final follow-up question. You said the outlook on your reflector business is the best you've seen in 10 years and yet last year was a pretty crappy year for commercial set orders. And this year is not looking any better year-to-date. So is that
componenttext: And just a final follow-up question. You said the outlook on your reflector business is the best you've seen in 10 years and yet last year was a pretty crappy year for commercial set orders. And this year is not looking any better year-to-date. So is that primarily reflecting just a higher value for the type of reflectors that you're developing? Or is it a market share game?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think what we see here is, over the last 5 years in our business, you got them as you know, a pretty high share of the hoop reflector or space reflector market. We've only sold 2 commercial reflectors. So far, we have this JC sat order for $37 milli
componenttext: No. I think what we see here is, over the last 5 years in our business, you got them as you know, a pretty high share of the hoop reflector or space reflector market. We've only sold 2 commercial reflectors. So far, we have this JC sat order for $37 million. We have 4 proposals out, we have 15 prospects in the pipeline. And what's driving this, Chris, are new entrants, it's the increase in high throughput satellites. It's recapitalization's. It's a surge that is occurring in small sats, U.S. government as well as the commercial sector. We see that as a pretty good opportunity in the near to medium term. And it's both on the reflector side as well as sensors and payloads for these other small sized both commercial and U.S. government. So I think we're on the front end of what it appears to be a recap cycle and we feel it's a very important recent event. And again, with the prospects we see and the proposals we have out, we feel pretty good about this business, Chris.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your first speaker for today, Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Yo
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce your first speaker for today, Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. You have the floor.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Rahul Ghai, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. And first, before we get starte
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Welcome to our third quarter fiscal 2016 earnings call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Rahul Ghai, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
And first, before we get started, a few words on forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements made today involve assumptions, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. For more information and a related discussion, please see the press release, the presentation and Harris' SEC filings. 
In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed today to comparable GAAP measures is included on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com, where a replay of this call will also be available.
And with that, Bill, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning, everybody. Third quarter results were solid with operational earnings benefiting from the continuing ramp in synergy savings. Total company orders and revenue were sequentially higher, and book-to-bill was a very st
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning, everybody. Third quarter results were solid with operational earnings benefiting from the continuing ramp in synergy savings. Total company orders and revenue were sequentially higher, and book-to-bill was a very strong 1.12, driven by Space and Intelligence Systems, Electronic Systems and Critical Networks. We delivered good bottom line results, despite the impact of lower tactical radio revenue from the Middle East, demonstrating that the added scale of the Exelis acquisition has broadened our business and is contributing to improve operating resiliency. 
Looking to the full year and the now-slower pace in the Middle East, together with a DoD tactical radio opportunity that has slipped into next year, we're adjusting our fiscal '16 earnings per share guidance to about $5.70, the bottom end of the prior range, on revenue of about $7.5 billion. Rahul will provide more color in a minute, but the only segment that's changing is Communication Systems, where we're now expecting legacy tactical revenue to be down high single digits with similar declines in both international and DoD. 
So let me start with a little color on what's driving the change. We started the year anticipating Harris legacy international of flat to down, even though we are coming off several years of strong expansion in international, including a record fiscal '15. But at the time, we had started to see some opportunities in the Middle East, market stretch out a bit. The first half of the year played out about as we thought, with international revenue up 5%, including higher revenue from the Middle East as a result of strong FMS funding support. And while we were expecting a year-over-year back-half decline in the Middle East, we anticipated sequential revenue growth. With the combination of fiscal pressures and funding priorities, both in-country and with the U.S. government as well as a slow FMS approval process, have shifted opportunities to the right. 
We believe the slow pace in the Middle East is temporary. Security issues and the need for more capable tactical communications are unchanged, and the FMS funding support remains strong for the region with additional money earmarked in the GFY '17 President's Budget request. 
In the U.S. tactical market, while our book-to-bill was above 1 in the quarter, MUOS upgrade opportunities expected in fiscal '16 are now unlikely to begin before the end of the year. While the MUOS capability is designed into our new 2-channel Manpack for the U.S. Army, what we've also adapted the wave form so that could be easily ported to a simple download into our 117G radios, 30,000 of which are currently fielded in DoD inventory. 
We've demonstrated connectivity between our radio and the satellite. We're on track to receive NSA certification shortly, and customers across several services are anxious to benefit from the mobility and higher bandwidth that the MUOS constellation provides. This is a very real and compelling value proposition for our customers, and funding for this opportunity has been earmarked in GFY '16. We anticipate this funding converting to an order for Harris before the end of September. 
So while fiscal '16 is a bit softer than expected in Tactical Communications, our outlook is solid and our competitive position has never been stronger. In the DoD, we've won or have a position on every major tactical radio contract awarded in the last 5 years: the mid-tier radio, MNVR, won in 2013; the Rifleman Radio, won last year; the SOCOM 2-channel handheld, won earlier this year; and most recently, the very large HMS Manpack, awarded in February. These are all significant wins for Harris, so let me update you on the latest developments. 
After more than 4 years of tenacious effort, the Army awarded Harris a 10-year $12.7 billion IDIQ contract for the multichannel Manpack radio, opening a market for Harris which had previously been closed to competition. Qualification and customer test are starting soon and scheduled to wrap up by the end of our fiscal '17, with the initial production delivery order award currently scheduled in early fiscal '18. The $3.7 billion Rifleman Radio procurement is also progressing well. We've now completed both qualification and customer tests, receiving positive feedback on operational capabilities, such as range and battery life. An initial production delivery order is expected in the second half of fiscal '17.
SOCOM's modernization is also moving forward, and a protest of Harris' single award for the $390 million 2-channel handheld radio program was recently resolved in our favor and work has begun. Product deliveries began in the first half of fiscal '18. This radio features both communications and ISR capabilities, and since SOCOM has long been an early adopter of cutting-edge technology that eventually finds its way into the broader DoD and international militaries, it positions us well to compete on a number of other modernization programs. The handheld is part of a broader modernization program that SOCOM is said to reach $900 million and include a new Manpack and HF radio. The Manpack RFP is expected late this summer and contract award before the end of fiscal '17, with the HF Radio following some time thereafter. 
On the international front, the pipeline remains about $2.9 billion and is diverse in terms of regions, countries and customers within a country. And while the near-term velocity has slowed a bit in the Middle East, continued progress is being made elsewhere. In the last earnings call, we mentioned that a $600 million opportunity for Australia's Phase 3 modernization had moved into the pipeline, with an award expected by the end of fiscal '17. We've now been selected as the preferred supplier with a significantly broader scope where Harris will now prime to deliver an integrated solution. This is a key part of our long-term growth strategy in international to expand our addressable market, leverage capabilities from across Harris and evolve from a radio supplier to now providing entire systems. 
Turning to a few highlights in other areas of the company. Both Space and Intel and Electronic Systems had strong orders, higher sequential and year-over-year organic revenue and book-to-bill greater than 1. Approximately 70% of Exelis' legacy business reside in these 2 segments and contributed to the positive sales and orders trend. 
In Space and Intel, awards from classified customers totaled $329 million, with continued strong budget support for intelligence programs and the ongoing customer focus on space superiority and protection capabilities. On the commercial space side, there are signs of a recapitalization cycle and fleet expansions beginning, and we recently received a $37 million order to provide an 18-meter unfurlable antenna reflector for the JCSAT-17 geostationary communications satellite. The prospects in our space antenna business are stronger today than they've been in the last decade. 
Within Electronic Systems, we enjoyed another quarter of strong electronic warfare bookings, including $88 million to supply electronic jammers for the F/A-18 aircraft, an excellent example of modernization opportunities on existing platforms with a very long tail. Electronic warfare is now on track in fiscal '16 to double orders over the prior year and end the year with about $200 million higher backlog. 
Strong free cash flow generation and deleveraging remain top priorities for Harris. And at the end of the third quarter, year-to-date free cash flow stood at $425 million, supporting expectations for the year of $750 million. On April 8, we completed the sale of Aerostructures and used the cash proceeds to pay down debt. So less than a year after closing the Exelis acquisition, we've repaid $683 million of term loan debt, which is approximately 1/3 of the total debt we've committed to repaying over 3 years. 
So now before turning the call over to Rahul Ghai, our new Chief Financial Officer, to cover the detailed financial results and guidance, I want to provide a brief introduction. 
As you already know, Rahul joined Harris in March of 2015 to lead the finance integration team and was named CFO in early February. By leading the finance integration team over the last year, Rahul has been essential to our integration success and has provided a smooth and natural transition to CFO. Rahul and I worked closely together for 5 of his 12 years at United Technologies, and again, over the past year as we've integrated Exelis. I'm confident in Rahul's ability to lead the Harris finance organization and be a true business partner to me and to the rest of the management team. 
So Rahul?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Before starting, I would like to remind you that our discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis. Now turning to third quarter results and Slide 3 in the presentation. EPS was $1.45, with acquisition savings su
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Before starting, I would like to remind you that our discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis. 
Now turning to third quarter results and Slide 3 in the presentation. EPS was $1.45, with acquisition savings supporting operating performance and benefiting from a lower-than-expected tax rate in the quarter. Reported revenue was $1.91 billion compared to $1.19 billion in the prior year. On an organic basis, revenue was down 3%. Strong revenue growth in Space and Intelligence Systems and Electronic Systems was more than offset by lower revenue in IT Services and International Tactical, in both legacy Harris and Exelis. Sequentially, revenue was up 3.6% with higher revenue across 3 of our 4 segments with the exception of the Communication Systems, where revenue was less than 1 point lower than revenue in the second quarter. 
EBIT margin for the company held strong at 16.4%, driven by excellent margin performance across all segments and reflecting continued focus on driving integration savings and lowering costs across the company. Orders in the quarter were $2.1 billion, bringing year-to-date book-to-bill to 1.06 company for the company and was greater than 1 in each segment in the third quarter, with the exception of Communication Systems. 
Within Communication Systems, third quarter book-to-bill for Tactical Communications was 0.8, with legacy Harris business at 0.83. And in the supplemental pages of the presentation, we have included historical order and backlog detail for legacy Harris tactical business. Public Safety book-to-bill was a bit disappointing at 0.5 and reflects that while the business is slowly improving with revenue up 15% in the quarter, we're not beyond the choppiness. 
In Space and Intelligence, order strength continued in the classified area. 
In Electronic Systems, orders were strong in electronic warfare and also in avionics, where we received $121 million in follow-on contracts for the F-35. 
In Critical Networks, FAA funding was a significant driver, and both CapRock energy and maritime reported book-to-bill of more than 1. 
For Harris overall, awards are on track to achieve a book-to-bill of 1 or close to 1 for the year. 
So turning to segment detail on Slide 4 and comparisons to prior year performance results as Exelis and Harris were combined for all of fiscal '15. 
Communication System third quarter revenue was $485 million and down 10%. Tactical Communication was down 16% and Public Safety was up 15% compared to the prior year. Higher tactical revenue in Europe and Central Asia was more than offset by lower revenue in Middle East for both Harris and Exelis legacy businesses and completion of Australia's Phase 2 modernization program. Operating income was $154 million and operating margin was a strong 31.8%. 
Turning to Space and Intelligence Systems on Slide 5. Third quarter revenue was $489 million and up 7% compared to prior year, driven by higher revenue from a number of new classified programs, including programs in Space Superiority. Operating income in the third quarter was $76 million and operating margin was 15.5%. Following the close of the quarter, Harris was awarded $81 million in follow-on contracts with $26 million ordered was sustained ground-based systems that support U.S. missile warning, missile defense and space surveillance missions from the Air Force for the SENSOR program. 
Turning to Electronic Systems on Slide 6. Third quarter revenue was $393 million and up 6.2% compared to prior year. Higher revenue from the F-35 program and counter IED systems was partially offset by lower revenue from Commercial Broadband Satellite Program terminals. Operating income in the third quarter was $75 million and operating margin was excellent at 19.1%. 
Just following the close of the quarter, we completed the sale of Aerostructures, which was part of the Exelis acquisition and reported within the Electronic Systems. While not material to Harris, we have included historical financial informations of Aerostructures for fiscal '15 and '16 in the supplemental section of the presentation. 
Turning to Critical Networks on Slide 7. Third quarter revenue was $551 million and down 10% compared to prior year. Higher revenue from FAA's NextGen modernization programs was more than offset for lower revenue in IT Services from the wind down of 2 major programs and lower revenue in CapRock's energy market. Operating income in the third quarter was $59 million and operating margin was 10.7%. 
So moving to Slides 8 and 9. Total company revenue guidance, on an organic basis, is revised from down 5% to 6% to down about 7%, driven by lower revenue in Communication Systems. The impact of lower revenue is expected to be partially offset by cost savings across the company and lower taxes. As a result, non-GAAP EPS is now expected to be approximately $5.70, the lower end of the previous guidance range. In Communication Systems, we now expect revenue to be down between 8% to 9%, with Harris legacy tactical down in single digits. With lower volume for the year, operating margin is expected to be about 29% in the segment, which is at the lower end of the previous range. 
In Electronic Systems, expectations remain unchanged with the exception of removing Aerostructures for the remainder of the year. With Aerostructures removed, revenue was revised to a range of down 3% to 4% and is equivalent to the previous organic expectations of down 2% to 3%. Operating margin is unchanged at 18% to 19%. And in Space and Intelligence and Critical Networks, expectations remain unchanged. 
The expected tax rate for fiscal '16 has been revised from 32.5% to 31% due to international tax settlements for prior years and from integration steps that have lowered state taxes. Beyond fiscal '16, we expect to benefit from lower state taxes and permanent R&D tax credit. 
So let me turn it back to Bill for a few closing comments.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Rahul. A little less than a year ago, we closed on Exelis, a truly transformational acquisition for our company. We're executing well on the integration, and the results are benefiting from synergy capture. From Day 1 of integration, we
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Rahul. A little less than a year ago, we closed on Exelis, a truly transformational acquisition for our company. We're executing well on the integration, and the results are benefiting from synergy capture. 
From Day 1 of integration, we've been tracking a little ahead of schedule and reaching integration targets, which is a great achievement from the team. So as we maneuvered through pockets of revenue softness, it's evident that the added scale of the Exelis acquisition has broadened our business and is contributing to improved operating resiliency. With less than a year into the acquisition, achieving our current expectation of about 11% earnings growth is a good outcome. 
Looking ahead, we expect fiscal '16's rising trend in earnings to continue into fiscal '17, supported by higher synergy savings and other cost reduction actions. In the meantime, we'll continue to gain traction in our multiyear strategy to successfully integrate Exelis, lower cost and deliver accretion, shape our business portfolio, drive strong free cash flow and deleverage, all while still investing in technology and new product development to drive future growth. 
And with that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski from Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, I guess on the Australia contract, it seems like one of the largest radio contracts you guys have won, as far as I remember. Is that through the protest period, I guess, number one? And number two, how much of a growth driver can that be for you in
componenttext: Bill, I guess on the Australia contract, it seems like one of the largest radio contracts you guys have won, as far as I remember. Is that through the protest period, I guess, number one? And number two, how much of a growth driver can that be for you in fiscal '17?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, as we've been named the preferred supplier but haven't won the award yet, we expect the contract award to occur sometime late in our fiscal '17, which means revenue from that opportunity extends into and begins in fiscal '18. So it's stil
componenttext: Well, first off, as we've been named the preferred supplier but haven't won the award yet, we expect the contract award to occur sometime late in our fiscal '17, which means revenue from that opportunity extends into and begins in fiscal '18. So it's still on the horizon. We are very well-positioned, being officially notified by the Australian MOD that we're the preferred supplier is a very, very important step in the contract negotiation phase. But we do expect that award to happen sometime in the late of our fiscal '17. It's very big, and we we're pleased with our progress there. And again, it's a key part of our long-term strategy to grow from a radio supplier to now a systems supplier. We've talked about that for the last few years.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: That's great. Is it fair to say the $2.9 billion international pipeline still includes Australia in it?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does.
componenttext: Yes, it does.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last one. I know we're still a quarter out. But directionally, in fiscal '17, can you give us a sense of your outlook for communications, just given its importance?
componenttext: Okay. And just last one. I know we're still a quarter out. But directionally, in fiscal '17, can you give us a sense of your outlook for communications, just given its importance?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- first of all, we're not going provide today any guidance. We're not -- we'll come to that in early August. But I think when you talk about communications, you sound -- your question seems more direct towards the tactical side, which as we kno
componenttext: Well, the -- first of all, we're not going provide today any guidance. We're not -- we'll come to that in early August. But I think when you talk about communications, you sound -- your question seems more direct towards the tactical side, which as we know, has been more of the important earnings driver. So we're not going to provide some guidance today, but there's several things that are on our radar screen that we'd like to see happen in the near term that will help us shape some of the guidance will provide in early August. In the DoD side, both MUOS and the MNVR radio, the mid-tier radio, together will contribute to higher earnings, higher revenue in fiscal '17. MUOS, which did slip out of the quarter, is we expect to receive certifications on that this summer, an NSA certification. We've already demonstrated on-air performance for both voice and data. It's well supported. Funds are allocated. And it's a very strong and compelling business case, and we're very proud [ph] if that's going to happen over the next several months. On the mid-tier side, on the MNVR, that will be in the tens of millions of dollars. It's well supported in the President's Budget request as well as in the NDAA that just came out. The network assessment is going on as we speak. And we expect a production award towards the end of government fiscal year '16, so around the September timeframe. I think on the international side, which has become a bigger part of our business and is a very large pipeline, we're looking at what's occurring in Eastern Europe and the Ukraine, where we've been very, very strong in fiscal '16. We need that to continue. We need to see the opportunities that we've seen very well in Iraq in fiscal '16. We expect that to continue at the same level as we've see in '16. And again, opportunities in Iraq to us, as we speak today, seem to be well supported. One of the opportunities in international had slipped out of fiscal '16 into '17 is in Iraq, but is well funded. We think that, that's going to happen in the '17. There's another country in the Middle East -- we can't name where an opportunity did slip out, and we expect that'll happen in early '17 as well. And then finally, in Central Asia, meaning specifically Afghanistan, we've had a very strong year this year. Opportunities there seem well supported. And we do expect Afghanistan, and more broadly, Central Asia to be a strong contributor to revenue into next year. Now outside of Tactical Communication, we have a broader business -- outside of legacy tactical, we have a broader communications business, including Exelis, the radio business from Exelis, which is mostly international. We've been tracking an opportunity in Saudi Arabia for quite some time. It's about $40 million, $50 million in size for SINCGARS radios for vehicles. It's been hung up in the Saudi Royal Court for a number of months, and we need that to break free as we get into '17 as well. So maybe Pete, just a little bit of shape and color around what we expect going into next year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gautam Khanna from Cowen and Company.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to follow-up on Pete's question, when we look at the absolute level of backlog at legacy Tactical, $419 million. It's a pretty low level. Obviously, that captures domestic and foreign. Why should we not be concerned about another down year in fiscal '1
componenttext: So to follow-up on Pete's question, when we look at the absolute level of backlog at legacy Tactical, $419 million. It's a pretty low level. Obviously, that captures domestic and foreign. Why should we not be concerned about another down year in fiscal '17 at tactical RF? Or are you willing to say, directionally, it's going to be flat, up, down? What's your sense? Because a lot of what you talked about looked like fiscal '18 sales opportunities.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll most of -- yes, we won't -- we're not going to comment yet on '17 and the shape, up, down, flat, at this point. We provided some additional information on the backlog in the document. I know some of the math that some of analysts have done on funded
componenttext: We'll most of -- yes, we won't -- we're not going to comment yet on '17 and the shape, up, down, flat, at this point. We provided some additional information on the backlog in the document. I know some of the math that some of analysts have done on funded backlog, where were at today, it is -- it's low. It's low as has been in some time. As we look at over the next 12 months and how much is covered in backlog, it's not all that different from where we were about a year ago. But we do see a number of things that are materializing, both in a DoD as well as in the international side, much of which we do expect over the course of next year. And it's good to see a lot of the international opportunities backstopped by strong funding support within the U.S. DoD and State Department funds.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us any color on the upcoming quarters? Do you expect book-to-bill to be -- you're implying about $300 million of legacy Tactical RF revenue in Q4. Do you anticipate that bookings will exceed that? Or come in below that? And how's it shaping i
componenttext: Can you give us any color on the upcoming quarters? Do you expect book-to-bill to be -- you're implying about $300 million of legacy Tactical RF revenue in Q4. Do you anticipate that bookings will exceed that? Or come in below that? And how's it shaping in fiscal Q1? You mentioned MNVR might actually get an award in the September quarter. Are there any other items you can point to, to help us kind of calibrate to what we should expect the next couple of quarters?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gautham. Over the course of Q4, we expect to end the year with funded backlog in Tactical, in line with Q3 or slightly up. So we do expect to see some decent awards in Q4 about at the level of revenue. So we don't see another step down in backlog at
componenttext: Yes, Gautham. Over the course of Q4, we expect to end the year with funded backlog in Tactical, in line with Q3 or slightly up. So we do expect to see some decent awards in Q4 about at the level of revenue. So we don't see another step down in backlog at this point, but in line with where we're at in -- where we are in Q3. We're not anticipating or providing any guidance on Q1 into '17. Although we are watching very carefully the network assessment. The funding for MNVR is in the '16 budget. There's money allocated in the '17 PBR. It seems to be protected in the NDAA that came out of HASC at about $20 million, $25 million. And we do anticipate a production award occurring in September timeframe. That could have -- that could drive revenue beyond that. It may not be in Q1. But we do think that, that's going to end up occurring as we get into '17.

componenttext: Yes. The scope of our work hasn't changed from what we've been communicating before. And this has been in the discussions with the Australian MOD for several years. We've got a very strong group of partners with us. We have a very well-defined scope, providing a broader system with radios, and it remains about $600 million.

componenttext: Well, we expect the customer test for the Manpack to occur between January and May of 2017, and we expect the first delivery order within August of 2017 decision and delivering around October of 2017. That is our expectation. As we've said before, we see the Manpack as a revenue driver in fiscal '18, not in fiscal '17.

componenttext: Yes. It's in the tens of millions of dollars that slipped beyond Q4 into Q1, Q2. It's possible we received the order late this quarter. It more likely is in Q1 of our fiscal '17. Over time, it's a pretty substantial opportunity. It's across a number of different services. And we feel very, very good about the capability. As I said in my prepared remarks, the business case on that is really very, very compelling. And we've demonstrated on-air performance of the 117G with MUOS already. And I think it's a great opportunity for us, and we're confident it's going to go forward. It may not happen this quarter.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. I guess, I'm sort of wondering more broadly -- when I look at the revenue outlook reduction, especially in Comm Systems, kind of how much of that is general softness across many areas, especially -- I guess, especially international versus the prior forecast as opposed to it being 1 or 2 or 3 bigger specific items that slipped into '17?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It really comes into 3 specific opportunities. One is MUOS for -- on the DoD side, which again is tens of millions, and dropped the guidance down to high single digits for the DoD side tactical radio in fiscal '16. That did slip to the right, but we'
componenttext: Yes. It really comes into 3 specific opportunities. One is MUOS for -- on the DoD side, which again is tens of millions, and dropped the guidance down to high single digits for the DoD side tactical radio in fiscal '16. That did slip to the right, but we're very confident that's going to happen. On the international side, we saw 2 opportunities slip to the right. One is in Iraq. And is -- does have funding. But we do expect that to be a first half '17 event, not in Q4 '16. And the other is an opportunity for another country in the Middle East, which we can't name. The funding for that opportunity has been reprioritized, but the customer's working with us on a number of other projects which we believe will be funded in the first half of our fiscal '17. So it's relatively isolated to 3 different specific opportunities that generally just moved our of the quarter.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Manpack award, some of your competitors have been talking about what they have to offer there. I was wondering if you could frame for us where you think Harris is positioned and why you think you're going to win?
componenttext: On the Manpack award, some of your competitors have been talking about what they have to offer there. I was wondering if you could frame for us where you think Harris is positioned and why you think you're going to win?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we have got a very, very strong and compelling offering. We've been working on it for a number of years. We have a very strong, very high share today in the Manpack market within the U.S. DoD. And we've developed, I think, a very good radio
componenttext: Well, we think we have got a very, very strong and compelling offering. We've been working on it for a number of years. We have a very strong, very high share today in the Manpack market within the U.S. DoD. And we've developed, I think, a very good radio in a very large factory where we've got tremendous scale. That through the R&D investments, we're able to continue to bring features and functionality of the radio over time and use our scale to make sure we're competitive on this cost side. So we think we've got a very, very strong offering for the Manpack.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly, you highlighted the debt repayment year-to-date, and you're about 1/3 of the way to your target. What do you think the profile of debt repayment will be going forward from here?
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly, you highlighted the debt repayment year-to-date, and you're about 1/3 of the way to your target. What do you think the profile of debt repayment will be going forward from here?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rahul. So I think we had said that will be about $2 billion in the first 3 years, so we're tracking to that. And in the first quarter of our fiscal '17 or just after the first quarter of fiscal '17, we have about $250 million of debt repayment on
componenttext: This is Rahul. So I think we had said that will be about $2 billion in the first 3 years, so we're tracking to that. And in the first quarter of our fiscal '17 or just after the first quarter of fiscal '17, we have about $250 million of debt repayment on one of the old Exelis notes that we will prepay. So I would say between -- so maybe a little bit kind of the same pattern between '17 and '18, and we'll evaluate as we get into fiscal '17 if we need to order that. But I would just spread that equally between '17 and '18 at this point, maybe a little bit lower in '17 and more in '18.
