headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Manpack award, some of your competitors have been talking about what they have to offer there. I was wondering if you could frame for us where you think Harris is positioned and why you think you're going to win.
componenttext: On the Manpack award, some of your competitors have been talking about what they have to offer there. I was wondering if you could frame for us where you think Harris is positioned and why you think you're going to win.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we have got a very, very strong and compelling offering. We've been working on it for a number of years. We have a very strong, very high share today in the Manpack market within the U.S. DoD. And we've developed, I think, a very good radio
componenttext: Well, we think we have got a very, very strong and compelling offering. We've been working on it for a number of years. We have a very strong, very high share today in the Manpack market within the U.S. DoD. And we've developed, I think, a very good radio in a very large factory where we've got tremendous scale. That through the R&D investments we're able to continue to bring features and functionality of the radio over time and use our scale to make sure we're competitive on the cost side. So we think we've got a very, very strong offering for the Manpack.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then secondly, you highlighted the debt repayment year-to-date, and you're about 1/3 of the way to your target. What do you think the profile of debt repayment will be going forward from here?
componenttext: Okay. And then secondly, you highlighted the debt repayment year-to-date, and you're about 1/3 of the way to your target. What do you think the profile of debt repayment will be going forward from here?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rahul. So I think we had said that we will be about $2 billion in the first 3 years, so we're tracking to that. And in the first quarter of our fiscal '17, or just after the first quarter of fiscal '17 we have about $250 million of debt repayment
componenttext: This is Rahul. So I think we had said that we will be about $2 billion in the first 3 years, so we're tracking to that. And in the first quarter of our fiscal '17, or just after the first quarter of fiscal '17 we have about $250 million of debt repayment on one of the old Exelis notes that we will prepay. So I would say between -- so maybe a little bit kind of the same pattern between '17 and '18. And we'll evaluate as we get into fiscal '17 if we need to alter that. But I would just spread that equally between '17 and '18 at this point. Maybe a little bit lower in '17 and more in '18.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we said is that also over the next 3 years we'll bring our leverage ratio down into the 1.5 range, and we're tracking well towards that.
componenttext: What we said is that also over the next 3 years we'll bring our leverage ratio down into the 1.5 range, and we're tracking well towards that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a final one for me. I was wondering if you could size how large your Middle Eastern export sales are in the communications division.
componenttext: Okay. And then just a final one for me. I was wondering if you could size how large your Middle Eastern export sales are in the communications division.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Middle East for us, in broadly Middle East, North Africa, is about 40%, 45% of our international tactical business.
componenttext: Middle East for us, in broadly Middle East, North Africa, is about 40%, 45% of our international tactical business.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to address maybe a strategic question. You talk about continuing to optimize the business portfolio. Clearly the sale of the Aerostructures business was a spectacular outcome. But optimize means lots of different things. So could you elaborate on
componenttext: I wanted to address maybe a strategic question. You talk about continuing to optimize the business portfolio. Clearly the sale of the Aerostructures business was a spectacular outcome. But optimize means lots of different things. So could you elaborate on that, please?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We feel very good about where we ended on the Aerostructures business and completing the sale in early April. It's on top of what we did last year on the commercial healthcare business and before that broadcast. So I think we've been, I think, pretty
componenttext: Yes. We feel very good about where we ended on the Aerostructures business and completing the sale in early April. It's on top of what we did last year on the commercial healthcare business and before that broadcast. So I think we've been, I think, pretty dispassionate, pretty aggressive in looking at what is in our portfolio, what strategically fits, what's a better value to Harris versus to an outside party. We also look at the performance of the underlying business. That's an important factor. But Howard, as I step back, we are at the heart a technology-based company, really in defense electronics, mission critical communications, and we want to be in businesses where technology is a discriminator, add some competitive advantage. We spend quite a bit on IRAD [indiscernible] and 4%, it's well above our peers, 4% of our revenue. We have about 40% of our population are engineers or scientists, and we want to be in businesses where technology can allow us to win. And that's a key factor at how we evaluate the portfolio. We've been, again, aggressive in doing something with Aerostructures, and we continue to look at what's in our based broader business that we have today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a lot of sense. And then just to build on that, can you talk -- we can see the cost synergies from Exelis. Can you talk about a little bit the sales synergies or where your -- where the organization is able to go to market with a package that c
componenttext: That makes a lot of sense. And then just to build on that, can you talk -- we can see the cost synergies from Exelis. Can you talk about a little bit the sales synergies or where your -- where the organization is able to go to market with a package that can somehow accelerate some growth? I mean, you did -- just to finish on that, you did a nice job, I think, of outlining what you're doing in radios, but the other markets are very large as well, and important.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our focus has been, Howard, really around the cost take-out. And we've done, I think, a very good job. We get at it very, very quickly. And we still feel good about hitting our run rate savings as we exit '17 in that $140 million, $150 million net ra
componenttext:
Yes. Our focus has been, Howard, really around the cost take-out. And we've done, I think, a very good job. We get at it very, very quickly. And we still feel good about hitting our run rate savings as we exit '17 in that $140 million, $150 million net range, which is more aggressive than we thought. We're closing about 15% of our floor space, and that's tracking very, very well. So that has been our #1 focus. And that's how we justified the acquisition. It was really on cost take-out. 
On the revenue side, yes, there -- we've got our teams really focused on this. Dana Mehnert, who's been here at Harris for more than 30 years and really built our Tactical Radio business into what it is today, has now taken on a role as Head of Global Business Development, really with an eye towards how do we grow in major markets around the world where the opportunities might be a little bit outside of the horizon or between businesses or might involve bringing together, strapping together some technology from Exelis with Harris. And his focus is really on that. And it's across the gamut. It's across technology, across platforms, across geographies or channels to market. In all those things we're starting to see some opportunities. 
And as we get beyond this year and start to shape '17 we'll talk a bit more about where they start to -- where we're starting to see those opportunities come to fruition. What I'd rather do is talk about the ones that we are actually achieving as we achieve them as opposed to speculating about where they might be. 
One last point on this, Howard, because I think this is very important, and I want to make sure investors don't miss this. It's not just about applying common technologies, going after channels. But part of what we're doing in driving operational excellence and integration into -- across Exelis is improving program performance. This is very important. The best way to grow a business is performing well on what you're doing today. And in the note that -- in Rahul's prepared remarks, he talked about the SENSOR program. The SENSOR program was being recompeted because the performance wasn't quite up to snuff with the Air Force. And through a lot of work, the on-time delivery of the program has improved dramatically. And now we're starting to get awards back on SENSOR. And the competition has been canceled, going to one of the pieces of SENSOR, because of the improved performance. So I feel if we just keep focused on performance and executing very, very well, that'll help us grow our business into the future as well.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then one last item. You've got -- again, sort of focused on the top line a little bit, you've got an enormous amount of data you provide to the FAA, and some of that can be remarketed and sold in a value-added manner. How far along are you with that?
componenttext: And then one last item. You've got -- again, sort of focused on the top line a little bit, you've got an enormous amount of data you provide to the FAA, and some of that can be remarketed and sold in a value-added manner. How far along are you with that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our focus right now with the FAA is executing on NextGen programs, and FAA today is probably our largest customer. We're on 4 or 5 NextGen programs. And of course we've got the FTI, the telecommunications infrastructure that we're working on. But th
componenttext: Well, our focus right now with the FAA is executing on NextGen programs, and FAA today is probably our largest customer. We're on 4 or 5 NextGen programs. And of course we've got the FTI, the telecommunications infrastructure that we're working on. But through Exelis, they have the ADS-B network, more than 640 radio towers operating very well, a long-term contract with the FAA. Very strong position. And they have unique access to data. And that data can be used in other forms for other uses, including supporting the integration of UAVs into the North American air traffic control system. That is a key part of our strategy. That's an opportunity that's likely beyond the next couple, 3-year planning horizon. But clearly, through both technology partnerships and legislation, all of which need to be worked on today to make sure we've got a strong position there over time. So Howard, that is an important focus of ours. And as we get clearer around our particular strategies there we'll share that more with investors. That's a little bit beyond the planning horizon.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- maybe this horse isn't quite dead yet, so I'll beat it again. But I want to talk Tactical really quickly. And I know you're not ready to provide '17 guidance, but you talked about several of these opportunities which clearly layer in later in next
componenttext: The -- maybe this horse isn't quite dead yet, so I'll beat it again. But I want to talk Tactical really quickly. And I know you're not ready to provide '17 guidance, but you talked about several of these opportunities which clearly layer in later in next fiscal year and beyond. And you've made a comment in your prepared remarks, in the closing remarks, about sort of short-term movements in revenue. But when you look at that business on a long-term trend line basis, is it your expectation that, that trend line is upward-sloping when we look out over the next 2, 3, 5 years because of all the opportunities that we've been looking at and you've executed on in recent years?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question, Carter. And clearly on the DoD side I think the answer is yes. It is clearly on an upward slope. And I think -- as I went into some detail on the programs we've won on the DoD side. And the fact that even in the President’s
componenttext:
I think it's a good question, Carter. And clearly on the DoD side I think the answer is yes. It is clearly on an upward slope. And I think -- as I went into some detail on the programs we've won on the DoD side. And the fact that even in the President’s budget they're well supported, in the DoD they're well supported, the procurements are moving going forward at a reasonable pace, I feel very confident that the DoD business will be a growth driver for us, certainly as we get into '18 and beyond. '17 is a little bit too soon to call. I do see it coming off the bottom in '16 into '17. But I think '18 is really the growth year. And I think it really relates to the flow-in from some of these modernization programs where we're very, very, well-positioned, including in SOCOM. So the DoD I think clearly is a growth driver. 
On the international side, we've seen fantastic growth over the last few years. We've seen a little bit of softness this year. The pipeline is still very robust. We are still well positioned. Competitively we're very strong. Where we are going out to compete we win, almost all the places that we are competing in around the world where we have a position. I think the opportunity in Australia, where we've become the preferred supplier for a very large contract which includes systems and products, is an important part of our strategy because we need to increase the size of the addressable market we're going after in international in order to continue to see growth in that international base over time. But I do see on the DoD side, yes, that, that will be a longer-term growth market for us.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And a couple of others. Just looking at the bookings trend and the revenue trend at CapRock, does that business looks like it's bottomed now from your perspective?
componenttext: Okay, great. And a couple of others. Just looking at the bookings trend and the revenue trend at CapRock, does that business looks like it's bottomed now from your perspective?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the good news, Carter, is that we haven't adjusted in our outlook for '16, we haven't changed it based on what's going on in the CapRock business. The energy business is still under a lot of pressure. And oil prices have recovered a little b
componenttext:
Well, I think the good news, Carter, is that we haven't adjusted in our outlook for '16, we haven't changed it based on what's going on in the CapRock business. The energy business is still under a lot of pressure. And oil prices have recovered a little bit, but still well down. A lot of the energy majors are reporting some pretty terrible numbers right now. For the year we still expect CapRock energy to be down about 25%. We were down in the 20% range-ish in the first half, and it will be worse than that, obviously, in the second half. As we get into Q4, we see the revenue in Q4 in CapRock energy to be on the order of about $60 million in the quarter. So if you just annualize that, you're sort of around $240 million for the year as we exit fiscal '16. 
And for perspective, in fiscal '16 overall, revenue in CapRock energy was around $290 million. So the math would imply that we'll see a little bit of another downturn on an annual basis in '17 over '16. '16, again, is down about 25% from fiscal '15. So we are seeing another step down as we get into next year. But it's not different than what we described last time and did -- and built into our guidance for this year. I guess, as you saw the CN margins, we're down a little bit sequentially. We did lose money in energy in Q3, but we've done quite a bit of restructuring, as we laid out to investors back in February, and we do expect the energy business to go back to profitability in Q4 and be less of a profit driver as we get into fiscal '17.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you say less of a profit driver, you -- [indiscernible]?
componenttext: When you say less of a profit driver, you -- [indiscernible]?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Less of an impact on top. Yes, exactly.
componenttext: Less of an impact on top. Yes, exactly.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one final one, just a clarification. The increase in the synergies clearly benefits the fourth quarter this year. But does that imply any change to the run rate synergy target on Exelis that you laid out before? Or this is just faster captu
componenttext: Okay. And then one final one, just a clarification. The increase in the synergies clearly benefits the fourth quarter this year. But does that imply any change to the run rate synergy target on Exelis that you laid out before? Or this is just faster capture?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's faster capture. We still expect to be at $140 million, $150 million net -- $140 million to $150 million net of what we give back to the government as we exit fiscal '17. So it's really just a faster capture this year at $80 million, $85 million. We s
componenttext: It's faster capture. We still expect to be at $140 million, $150 million net -- $140 million to $150 million net of what we give back to the government as we exit fiscal '17. So it's really just a faster capture this year at $80 million, $85 million. We see next year, in year fiscal '17, integration savings or synergy savings in the $130 million to $135 million range, Carter. So that implies an extra $50 million in the in-year '17 from '16.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Seth Seifman from JPMorgan.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize in advance for asking another 2017 question. But not in terms of numbers, but just very broadly, outside of communications, when we think about the DoD budget and investment account outlays, it should be up pretty nicely in government fiscal '
componenttext: I apologize in advance for asking another 2017 question. But not in terms of numbers, but just very broadly, outside of communications, when we think about the DoD budget and investment account outlays, it should be up pretty nicely in government fiscal '17. When we think about Space and Electronics and, let's say, Critical Networks, putting CapRock aside, with DoD investment account outlays growing nicely, is there any reason to expect that any of those segments won't grow?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we see very good trends through the year in our Space business as well as in the Electronic Systems business. It's kind of encouraging to be through the year here in Space and pretty good backlog growth, pretty good book-to-bill through the year. Sa
componenttext: Well, we see very good trends through the year in our Space business as well as in the Electronic Systems business. It's kind of encouraging to be through the year here in Space and pretty good backlog growth, pretty good book-to-bill through the year. Same thing on the Electronic Systems business. It was good to see Electronic Warfare to be pretty strong, it turns out, over the course of the year and ending a couple of hundred million dollars higher in backlog. At least that bodes well for not another step-down as we get into '17. But yes, the budgets look pretty good. There's still a long way to go between where we are today in appropriations bills. But we feel pretty good about the overall outlook. The only cautionary points I would give is on CapRock. We do see, again, another step-down as we get into '17, just based on where the exit rate happens to be. And our mission is to sustain the business, which was down this year, in the 20%, 22%, 23% range, mainly because of a couple of big program roll-offs. We've got some work to do there to make sure that we hold that business as we go into next year. It's a very, very competitive landscape. We have about 1/3 of that business that's up for recompete. As we go into next year the mission is to sustain our services business. And we've got to do a little work to make sure that we win on those recompetes. That's something that this management team is pretty well focused on today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe as a follow-up on cash flow. You maintained the free cash flow guidance for the year but the CapEx guidance came down. I was wondering if you can talk about the driver there. I mean, was it basically that the uppers in the EPS guidance were kind
componenttext: And maybe as a follow-up on cash flow. You maintained the free cash flow guidance for the year but the CapEx guidance came down. I was wondering if you can talk about the driver there. I mean, was it basically that the uppers in the EPS guidance were kind of noncash versus the decline in the communications revenue? And then you still got a pretty big jump in the CapEx in Q4, and what specifically is driving that?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- yes, you're right. I mean, there's no change to our fiscal '16 guidance on cash flow. The reduction in CapEx is basically offsetting the change in earnings. So that's where -- that's kind of the math we're doing. We still need to get some working ca
componenttext: So -- yes, you're right. I mean, there's no change to our fiscal '16 guidance on cash flow. The reduction in CapEx is basically offsetting the change in earnings. So that's where -- that's kind of the math we're doing. We still need to get some working capital improvement in the fourth quarter to get to our full year number. But historically 50% of our cash flow for the year has come in the fourth quarter. And this year we're expecting slightly less than that. So we feel good about that. I mean, we have some projects going on. And the timing of CapEx kind of differs from quarter-to-quarter, and there's just variability within the quarter. So we have some projects going on that needs some step-up in CapEx. But we've calculated that outlook for the year, and we feel we'll be close to that number that we've guided to.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we feel pretty good, Seth, about the progress we've made over the last several years and just making ourselves a little more capital efficient. And it includes the approval thresholds in the company. On a pro forma basis a couple of years ago, the co
componenttext: Yes, we feel pretty good, Seth, about the progress we've made over the last several years and just making ourselves a little more capital efficient. And it includes the approval thresholds in the company. On a pro forma basis a couple of years ago, the companies together would have been around $260 million, $270 million or in a range of 3% of sales. And this year we'll be about 2.3%. We still see some opportunities to continue to be a little more judicious on capital spending going forward. So we feel pretty good about where we stand so far this year in capital.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This last question is from the line of Chris Quilty from Raymond James.
componenttext: This last question is from the line of Chris Quilty from Raymond James.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, just a follow-up on Australia and your -- the focus on systems. Can you give us an idea of what you end up bundling in, in a systems sale in addition to radios and what kind of a revenue multiplier or -- I mean, does it increase the size of the pote
componenttext: Bill, just a follow-up on Australia and your -- the focus on systems. Can you give us an idea of what you end up bundling in, in a systems sale in addition to radios and what kind of a revenue multiplier or -- I mean, does it increase the size of the potential order by 10% or 50% or double it?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we include -- the radios would also include a lot of antenna systems, it's the battle management systems, the software systems. There's a variety of other things that we package in to a systems offering to a customer. Every end market's going to be
componenttext: Well, we include -- the radios would also include a lot of antenna systems, it's the battle management systems, the software systems. There's a variety of other things that we package in to a systems offering to a customer. Every end market's going to be a little bit different. We've had several hundred million dollars’ worth of systems opportunity being booked and sold in other markets in the past. If I remember right, on those markets, because I don't want to talk specifically about Australia, it's probably in the order of around maybe 2:1. So 2 parts of non-radios to 1 part radios. So in other words, about 1/3 of the opportunity would be radios, or thereabouts, and that 2/3 would be other things you package around that.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you look at your opportunity pipeline down the road broadly, what percent of those international opportunities might you convert to more of a systems versus a traditional radio sale?
componenttext: And when you look at your opportunity pipeline down the road broadly, what percent of those international opportunities might you convert to more of a systems versus a traditional radio sale?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. That's something we've been working on for quite some time in the U.S. The U.S. military tends to do their own systems integration. They manage each of the suppliers and the components and then integrate it together and then tes
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. That's something we've been working on for quite some time in the U.S. The U.S. military tends to do their own systems integration. They manage each of the suppliers and the components and then integrate it together and then test it through what we're seeing today in these network evaluations, in these NIEs. On the international side, more and more customers are moving towards buying an installed solution, an integrated solution. And that's, I think, a good trend that's heading in our direction. We feel very good that the radio itself is very, very competitive and provides a key source of value, and we think we can broaden that and bring other partners on to our team. In fact, that's exactly what we've been able to do in Australia. Some very important large global players are on the Harris team in Australia providing components to us. And what that does is not just provide the radio but software and other components around that. It does continue to build more stickiness into that end customer coming back to Harris Corporation over time. So we feel very good about the trajectory we happen to be on in the systems and integrated solution side internationally.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And who would be your big competitors that are adopting the same approach?
componenttext: And who would be your big competitors that are adopting the same approach?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't want to get into the competitor mix because some of the competitors have found their way on to our team in Australia, and it really varies by market. But I will just say that we've got a lineup of very good suppliers, good partners with us i
componenttext: Well, I don't want to get into the competitor mix because some of the competitors have found their way on to our team in Australia, and it really varies by market. But I will just say that we've got a lineup of very good suppliers, good partners with us in Australia. And again, we go compete against different people in different markets.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a clarification on the MUOS. Is that a one-time revenue opportunity on the software upgrade or is there any kind of tail?
componenttext: Okay. And a clarification on the MUOS. Is that a one-time revenue opportunity on the software upgrade or is there any kind of tail?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's going to be a -- we've been investing quite a bit of IRAD into developing the ability to easily port this MUOS waveform into 117Gs. It sounds more simple in the way I explain it than it really was. There was quite a bit of magic to make this
componenttext: Well, there's going to be a -- we've been investing quite a bit of IRAD into developing the ability to easily port this MUOS waveform into 117Gs. It sounds more simple in the way I explain it than it really was. There was quite a bit of magic to make this happen and not require any sort of firmware, hardware change-out for these radios, which I think is absolutely amazing, amazing what the team has done. And what we're now doing is working with our service partners to provide them software licenses that would allow them to, once they buy the license, to then download that software into their radios, into their 117Gs. As that MUOS waveform is changed or advanced over time, there may be opportunities for that to kind of get readvanced or other licenses or other opportunities -- revenue opportunities to occur. But we see that over time this is in -- this is a pretty substantial opportunity. And I think as each service picks it up will drive some revenue event for us on MUOS.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a final follow-up question. You said the outlook on your reflector business is the best you've seen in 10 years, and yet last year was a pretty crappy year for commercial SATCOM orders, and this year is not looking any better year-to-date. So is
componenttext: And just a final follow-up question. You said the outlook on your reflector business is the best you've seen in 10 years, and yet last year was a pretty crappy year for commercial SATCOM orders, and this year is not looking any better year-to-date. So is that primarily reflecting just a higher value for the type of reflectors that you're developing? Or is it a market share gain?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think what we're seeing here is, over the last 5 years in our business, and we've got, as you know, a pretty high share of the hoop reflector or space reflector market, we've only sold 2 commercial reflectors. So far we have this JCSAT order for $37
componenttext: No. I think what we're seeing here is, over the last 5 years in our business, and we've got, as you know, a pretty high share of the hoop reflector or space reflector market, we've only sold 2 commercial reflectors. So far we have this JCSAT order for $37 million. We have 4 proposals out. We have 15 prospects in the pipeline. And what's driving this, Chris, are new entrants. It's the increase in high throughput satellites. It's recapitalizations. It's a surge that is occurring in small SATs relative to the U.S. government as well as the commercial sector. We see that as a pretty good opportunity in the near to medium term. And it's both on the reflector side as well as sensors and payloads for these other small sites, both, again, commercial and U.S. government. So I think we're on the front end of what appears to be a recap cycle, and we feel it's a very important recent event. And again, with the prospects we see and the proposals we have out, we feel pretty good about this business, Chris.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call may be recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Pamela
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Harris Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call may be recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Pamela Padgett, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I'm Pamela Padgett. And on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Rahul Ghai, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. First, a few words on forward-looki
componenttext: Hi. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I'm Pamela Padgett. And on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Rahul Ghai, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. First, a few words on forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements made today involve assumptions, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. From more information and the related discussion, please eat up at least presentation here and SEC filings. In addition, reconciliation of non-GAAP financial matters discussed today to comparable GAAP measures is included on the quarterly materials on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com, where a replay of this call is also available. And with that Bill, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning everybody. Overall, fiscal '16 was a solid year, and I'm pleased with our performance. Earnings per share increased 11% to $5.70 on organic revenue down 7%. Operating margins were up 60 basis points to 60.2%
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning everybody. Overall, fiscal '16 was a solid year, and I'm pleased with our performance. 
Earnings per share increased 11% to $5.70 on organic revenue down 7%. Operating margins were up 60 basis points to 60.2% and free cash flow was strong at $772 million. Book-to-bill was greater than 1. And we executed well against the key priorities we set out at the beginning of the year. First was a successfully integrated Exelis, a company which added scale, a broader portfolio of technologies, new market opportunities and improved operating resilience, and we're moving faster and achieving greater savings than initially expected. We exited fiscal '16, year 1 of integration at a net savings run rate of $120 million, the top end of what we originally committed to by year 3. And we're tracking well towards achieving $140 million to $150 million net as we exit fiscal '17. The second priority was to continue to reshape our portfolio. And in April, we saw the aerostructures business we acquired with Exelis at an attractive multiple using the proceeds to pay down debt. The third priority was to maximize free cash flow when we exceeded our guidance of $750 million to tight management of capital spending and a 4-day improvement in working capital, absorbing over $100 million in cash, restructuring and integration costs and $174 million in cash pension contributions. 
And finally, our fourth priority was the deleverage. And during the year, we retired $650 million in debt. About 1/3 of our 3-year debt reduction goal, allowing us to rebalance our capital deployment priorities as we reinitiate share repurchases in fiscal '17, with a placeholder of $150 million. And we executed these priorities while also continuing to drive operational excellence deep into the company to lower cost and improved program execution, reinvesting some of the savings in R&D to drive future growth. Company-funded R&D was again, this year, a little more than 4% of revenue, a spending rate higher than our peers, and what led to a number of important strategic wins. So let me provide a few highlights in the quarter before I discuss our detailed segment financial performance.
Fourth quarter earnings per share was $1.45, up 10%, with the results benefiting from the acquisition of lower tax rate and improved operating performance. Operating profit was up 6% and margin improved by 190 basis points, on organic revenue down 6%. Improved performance was driven by the capture synergy savings, lower cost and solid execution within space and intelligence, Electronic Systems and Critical Networks, all contributing to higher income and higher margin.
Space and Intel had another terrific quarter with revenue up 10% and operating margin up of 510 basis points, following an equally important impressive Q3, with continued strength in the classified area, including Space Superiority and protection. We're successfully leveraging our broader technology portfolio. And in the quarter, we were awarded a $104 million contract as prime in a new classified mission area that could potentially develop into another key franchise for Harris. 
In the commercial space market, we're seeing the beginning of a recapitalization and fleet expansion cycle. Following an award in Q3, for a new 18-meters space reflector, we received in the fourth quarter, a contract from Airbus for a 12-meter folded rib reflector for the European space agency's biomass satellite. Our opportunity pipeline in this area remains robust heading into fiscal '17. 
Electronic Systems also delivered excellent results with revenue up 4%, driven by higher electronic warfare and counter IED sales and 910 basis points of margin expansion. Electronic warfare was up in both Q3 and Q4, coming off a weak first half, and we continue to win modernizations on legacy platforms with orders for the year doubling over prior year. And significantly following the close of the quarter, ES received a 2-year $189 million contract from a country in the Middle East to provide the land forces with an integrated data management system, showcasing our competitive strength as a prime contractor, providing an integrated solution. The contract is for 1 brigade. But there are opportunities to add 3 more land brigades, sustainment, radios and operations center to incorporate air, navy and ground force communications. This contract also positions us well for similar projects in other countries in the region. And while Critical Networks were down 6%, it was better-than-expected. And strong cost controls and program execution along with savings from prior quarter restructuring actions at CapRock drove 310 basis points of margin expansion in this segment. On the other end of the spectrum, Communication Systems was weaker-than-expected with revenue down 24% and margins 250 basis points lower than prior year. Tactical Communications declined 29% with legacy Harry's down 40% with book-to-bill of 0.92. 
In the international market, funding remains relatively solid but our $1.77 billion follow-on contract that supports foreign military sales took longer to finalize than expected. And coupled with an overburdened administrative approval process for task orders cost several opportunities to stretch out beyond the end of the year. In July, we booked all the revenue that slipped from 4Q. The U.S. tactical market was also during the quarter as the starting to see more cautious customer buying behavior in advance of a likely CR this fall. So while I'm disappointed by the fall off in communications system, I'm really proud of how the team responded to meet the earnings and cash flow guidance presented in our Q3 call, pointing to the operating resilience of the new post-acquisition Harris. 
Today, we're initiating guidance for fiscal '17, reflecting continued progress and solid execution of our strategy. We expect earnings per share of $5.70 to $5.90, flat to up 4% on organic revenue, down 1% to 4%, with operating margin continuing to increase due to synergies, lower costs and pension tailwind. And with another year of strong free cash flow. We've set fiscal '17 guidance expectations for tactical in line with a slower environment we're currently experiencing, and we believe we're being appropriately conservative in our estimates. 
So before turning the call over to Rahul to provide some detailed segment results and guidance, I'd like to comment on the joint press release with Jenna Partners issued earlier today. As a result of constructive engagement with Jana, we reached an agreement to appoint 2 mutually agreed independent directors to our board. One will be announced in early September, and both will be nominated in our proxy for the October Annual Meeting. We have an ongoing dialogue with all of our shareholders, and we welcome their input. We have a long history of strong corporate governance, and we're firmly committed to maximizing long-term value for all of our shareholders. We look forward to the contributions that these 2 new directors will bring to the board. So with that, let me turn it over to Rahul.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Just to remind you, discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis. So turning now to segment detail on Slide 5 and comparisons to prior year pro forma results. Organic revenue comparisons, exclude aerostructures
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill, and good morning, everyone. Just to remind you, discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis. 
So turning now to segment detail on Slide 5 and comparisons to prior year pro forma results. Organic revenue comparisons, exclude aerostructures and just like prior quarters, Exelis and Harris, were combined for all of fiscal '15. Communication Systems segment revenue was $436 million, and down 24% compared to prior year. Tactical Communications were down 29% and public safety, down 10%. Higher tactical revenue in Europe and Central Asia was more than offset by lower tactical revenue in Northern Africa due to the expected completion of a large modernization and by a lower revenue in the Middle East. And even though the Middle East market remains relatively soft, revenue from the region was up sequentially. Operating income in the fourth quarter was $120 million and operating margin was still strong at 27.5%, even on much lower revenue. We ended the year with legacy tactical backlog of $402 million, and slightly lower than the third quarter backlog of $419 million as a result of orders that pushed out from the $1.77 billion IDIQ from the fourth quarter just built just referenced. 
On Slide 11, we have again included historical information for legacy tactical orders, revenue and backlog.
Turning to Space and Intelligence Systems on Slide 6. Revenue was $529 million, up 10% compared to prior year, driven by higher revenue from a number of new classified programs, including in the area of space priority and protection. Operating income in the fourth quarter was $83 million and operating margin was strong at 15.7% compared with last year's operating margin of 10.6%. In addition to the classified orders that Bill has already addressed, Harris was awarded a 3-year $38 million contract for a large baseline imager modules for weather monitoring above goes our satellites. This win is an excellent example of the complimentary nature of combining Exelis' sensibility for satellite ground processing capability. 
Turning to electronic systems on Slide 7. Revenue was $381 million and up 4% on an organic basis compared to prior year, with higher revenue in electronic warfare and counter IED systems. Operating income in the fourth quarter was $73 million and operating margin was solid at 19.2% compared with last year's operating margin of 10.1%. 
Turning to Critical Networks on Slide 8. Revenue was $575 million and down 6% compared to prior year. Higher revenue from FAA's NextGen modernization program was more than offset by lower revenue in IT Services and from the wind down of 2 major programs mentioned in previous earnings calls, and lower revenue in CapRock's energy business. 
Operating income in the fourth quarter was $81 million and operating margin was 14.1%. Margin improvement was in large part driven by previous CapRock cost reduction actions that resulted in a CapRock's energy business returning to profitability in the fourth quarter despite a significantly lower revenue than the third quarter.
So moving to Slide 9 and 10. Today, we are initiating fiscal GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $5.53 to $5.73 and non-GAAP EPS in a range of $5.70 to $5.90. Non-GAAP EPS excludes about $30 million to $35 million of integration costs. To remind you, non-GAAP guidance still includes approximately $132 million or about $0.70 per share of Exelis acquisition intangible amortization. Revenue is expected to be in the range of $7.1 billion to $7.3 billion, down 1% to 4% an organic basis, excluding aerostructures. EPS guidance reflects a change in FAS accounting methodology. Today, we have used -- historically, we have used a single discount rate for calculating the interest and service cost associated with pension obligations. Beginning in fiscal '17, we will measure the FAS fashion cost in a given year using a spot rates approach. We adopted this approach as we believe it provides a more precise measurement of our pension service and interest cost since it matches each year's individual spot rates to the projected cash flows in that year. We also reduced our expected pensions asset rate of return assumption by 25 basis points to 7.75% for 2017. EPS guidance also includes $150 million in share repurchases plans during the year. Other EPS guidance details are outlined on Slide 9, including an expected tax rate of 31%, in line with fiscal '16 results. We expect free cash flow to be approximately $800 million in fiscal '17. We ended fiscal '16 with 49 days of working capital, a reduction of 4 days from the beginning of the year. Our fiscal '17 guidance reflects continued improvement in working capital performance and GAAP spend of approximately $175 million.
Turning now to segment guidance. In communications system, revenue is expected to be down 7% to 9%, with significant decline in Tactical Communications and Public Safety trending higher. Within Tactical Communications, Harris legacy DoD is expected to be flat to up and legacy international, down in mid-teens. In legacy DoD, we expect fourth quarter's cautious buying behavior to continue. However, we also expect and initial Army modernization to contribute to revenue in the tens of millions each. And legacy international, since the third quarter earnings calls, our views have not changed significantly on where we expect areas of opportunity and challenges in fiscal '17. Overall, we expect revenue to be once again underpinned by FMS funding support for opportunities in Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa and Central Asia. Segment operating margin is expected to be in the range of 29.5% to 30.5%, reflecting the impact of lower revenue offset by synergies from the Exelis acquisition. In Space and Intelligence Systems, revenue is expected to be up 1% to 3%, with continuing strength in classified and uptick in commercial space. Segment operating margin is expected to be in the range of 16% to 17%. In electronic systems, revenue is expected to be up 1% to 3% on an organic basis. Revenue will be higher in electronic warfare, driven by the growth in backlog in 2016 and given the recent significant $189 million win that Bill just referenced. Segment operating margin is expected to improve to a range of 20% to 21%. 
In Critical Networks, revenue is expected to be down 3% to 6%, with mission network's revenue trending higher due to a solid FAA franchise and international air traffic management opportunities. This has been more than offset by continued weakness in CapRock Energy and still tough comparisons for IT services. For IT Services, we expect revenue to stabilize at approximately $225 million to $250 million a quarter. Segment operating margin is expected to be in a range of 12% to 13%. 
So now let me turn it back to Bill for a few closing comments.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, Rahul. Overall, fiscal '16 was a solid year, excellent progress in a multiyear strategy to successfully integrate Exelis and realize the full synergies and accretion. We'll continue to drive our operational excellence program to not
componenttext: Okay. Well, thank you, Rahul. Overall, fiscal '16 was a solid year, excellent progress in a multiyear strategy to successfully integrate Exelis and realize the full synergies and accretion. We'll continue to drive our operational excellence program to not only lower cost but also to streamline processes, improve program execution and increase customer satisfaction. And we'll continue to reinvest in R&D to grow our core franchises and address near adjacencies where technology and innovation are differentiators. An important part of our strategy to drive shareholder value is optimizing our business portfolio by focusing on investments in which technology provides differentiation. We dispassionately, objectively and assess business are strategically fit in our better value to Harris as well as which businesses may be a better value on their own or with a third-party. When we believe a business is not core to our strategy to drive shareholder value, we undertake proactive steps as evidenced by the recent sale of Aerostructures and the sale of our commercial health care and broadcast communications businesses in prior years. We'll continue to assess our portfolio with a goal of enhancing shareholder value creation. And as Rahul just described, fiscal '17 guidance. While we still expect revenue headwinds to persist, we also expect additional acquisition savings in our continuing focus on lowering costs to result in higher fiscal '17 earnings. Our guidance anticipates a continuing resolution through the end of this calendar year and the spending constraints it typically creates until the budget is passed, especially in our shorter-cycle tactical business. Longer-term, we expect positive momentum to Space & Intel and Electronic Systems to continue. And we also anticipate a recovery in the tactical market driven by Army and SOCOM modernizations as well as other international modernization such as Australia and in the Middle East and North Africa. And with that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Let me start with CapRock. The -- we exit the year about what we thought, about $60 million in the quarter in CapRock Energy. So it was down quite a bit year-over-year in the fourth quarter, probably around 35%. For the year in '16, down about
componenttext: Yes, sure. Let me start with CapRock. The -- we exit the year about what we thought, about $60 million in the quarter in CapRock Energy. So it was down quite a bit year-over-year in the fourth quarter, probably around 35%. For the year in '16, down about 25%. With sitting down in the low 40s, now was a bit of incremental pressure. Although there is some service companies that are out there expecting some recovery and to '17 and maybe the back end of '17. We do see another step down next year. We were sizing it at about 25%. We took some pretty aggressive restructuring actions, really, over the last 12 to 18 months. But you recall pretty significantly as we exit to Q2. And those have started to take hold. We must Manny and CapRock Energy in Q3. We returned to profitability in Q4. And that's part of the reason why you see to see a network, Critical Network segment, being more profitable in Q4. Profit comes from some turn around on the CapRock business. So I think we sized it for next year. We expect a big money in CapRock Energy next year. But we do see another step down in that segment again, about 25%. On the services side, we were down 10%, 11% in the services in the year, down about 22% in the services side mission sustainment, which was about what we had expected, maybe a little bit better in Q4 but about what we expected. We do see another step down next year, sort of in the high single-digit range. We have a pretty good pipeline of opportunities. We ended fiscal '16  in that business with a book-to-bill of 1. So are helping backlog in the next of the year. We're previously said about 1/3 of that business was up for we can feed and it's going to put pressure into '17. When I'll get into that pressure into '17. But some of the recompetes are now behind us. And if for very pretty well, we may be at ahead of us. And what we're seeing here is that the recompetes are we're winning them, we do when them. The common single vendor IDIQs instead of regular contracts. So we still have to compete for task orders. So we do revenue pressure in '17 in services. But not quite at the downturn we saw in '16, Howard.

componenttext: Bill, I think around the time of the acquisition, you put out a long-term cash flow target, I think for fiscal '19 of $1 billion for free cash flow. And so the forecast for '17 is $800 million. Is that target still operative? And can you talk about the ways to get there?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In fact, we feel very good first about we came out in fiscal '16 with lots of puts and takes above the $750 million guidance. So we came in at $772 million. And we feel good about how we deliver that, absorbing pretty substantial pension and cash in
componenttext: Sure. In fact, we feel very good first about we came out in fiscal '16 with lots of puts and takes above the $750 million guidance. So we came in at $772 million. And we feel good about how we deliver that, absorbing pretty substantial pension and cash integration cost. Very good improvement in working capital as we had signaled we would have. We continued to tightly manage our capital spending. So next year, we guided to about $800 million in free cash flow with a little bit of a step up in capital spending although we remain very, very tight on that at $175 million. We still see a pack to get into $1 billion by fiscal '19, that was a 3-year goal that we set out. And it comes from the same things we described before on this call. So with integration savings rolling this year sort of hit really growing going into '18. We see lower cash integration cost. Was a lower cash interest expense as we see some additional working capital performance improvements. And since we have closed about 50% of our floor space and about 2 million square feet, we do see some additional capital spending efficiencies as we get further out in time. So those are the still -- they still remain set to be the key drivers of hitting $1 billion in '19.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not going to give guidance on the book-to-bill. What we've given guidance on today is what we think is going to happen in the revenue environment. We see the DoD business to be flat up a little bit slightly going into next year. We ended the y
componenttext: Well, we're not going to give guidance on the book-to-bill. What we've given guidance on today is what we think is going to happen in the revenue environment. We see the DoD business to be flat up a little bit slightly going into next year. We ended the year around $70 million more or less in Q4. You see it in the back of the appendix in the DoD tactical business. We see that same cautious behavior continuing into next year. But then on top of that, we see tens of millions  of opportunities into areas as Rahul mentioned, modernization opportunities which could include the MNVR opportunities as well as on and that should bring us to flat top slightly. We do see another step down next year in the international business. We see that our pipeline still remains pretty healthy in that business. But we do see that business down sort of mid-teens going into next year. Not a lot really has changed in many ways since our Q3 release in terms of the overall sets of risks and opportunities we see out there. We'll still see some good funding on the horizon. But we see that business down a little bit going into next year. And maybe, Noah, just to give you a little bit more color on this. As we look into '17, we see about 1/3 of that business is in Europe which as you know, with the topic for in '16, was coming up a pretty good record Eastern Europe and Ukraine remain very, very solid. We still see that strong going into '17 but will be down slightly from what was a record year. We see about 1/3 of the businesses in the Middle East and Africa. Where we do expect to see a relatively slow pace to continue, revenue to be flat to down slightly. Iraq remains one of our biggest opportunities in the Middle East. There's another country in the Middle East which will is a little bit of a recovery offset that. But again, that Middle East, Africa should be probably down slightly to a flat next year. The balance of the business are about 10% to 50% each in AsiaPac and Australia. Australia should be that up a little bit because Israeli is going to come in a little bit stronger next year. We see Central America, Latin America to be flat to up slightly a little bit. We do see Brazil a little bit weaker. We see Mexico a little bit stronger. But that region up a little bit. But really, as we look out into the next year, the big challenge we're facing is really in Central Asia. And particular in Afghanistan is a pretty broad program runs from a lots of new radios is in the past or sustainment in '17 and beyond. And actually did biggest piece of headwind going into next year.

componenttext: So I appreciate all that color. That's helpful. I think you're just starting your fiscal '17. You've us fiscal '17. So it's all unfair to go down this line of questioning. But I think that investors in the market are not particularly concerned with '17 and are looking further out because if  one of these new programs that don't kick in until after '17, the defense budget is only just starting to bottom. And so there's a lot of potential positive prospects beyond '17. But on the other hand, your bookings keep trending to be relatively soft. You're talking about softer DoD cautious buying  behavior, which not particularly consistent, with a guess, a lot of other defense companies were saying. And so a point being, as far as a lot of uncertainty around the gross trajectory beyond '17, recognizing that most fair question given where you are. I do know if there's any way you could speak to those inputs even directionally to get some people comfort in that part of the model.

componenttext: Yes, sure. Look, while we're seeing some pressure in '17, when you down 1% to 3% -- 1% to 4% next year. We've got 2 business segments that are coming up and coming off of a pretty good back half. That's Electronic Systems and Space & Intel. So those are performing very, very well, and we expect that they continue. Within Critical Networks, we see our mission networks FA business it has been strong this past year, very strong in the second half of '16, continuing up next year. Good international opportunities. So we see that continuing to grow going into next year. We think services is going to stabilize as we go beyond '17 and '18. So it won't be much of a drag. And on the CS segment, was he that segment down next year. But when you look at 2 things. Web-mac, to visible words and actions happening on Army modernization, SOCOM organization. Those activities are moving quickly. Our Rifleman Radio is now through both customer test and call test. The Manpack radio is now through qualification test. They expect to go into delivery orders into early part of our Harris fiscal '18. SOCOM is  moving nicely. We do see substantial budget upticks in '17 from '16 as well as in '18 from '17. So very good strong funding support for that. On the international side, the pipeline remains very, very strong. The needs are out there. The funding is not moving at base as we had expected. But there's a strong need that's out there. The pipeline is pretty robust and going out beyond '17, we see markets like Australia big significant who go into '18. So we still believe that '18 will be a growth year for Harris Corporation, and I think we're positioning ourselves well to grow in that time period.

componenttext: Look, I'm not going to give much color around book-to-bill for the year. The big opportunity that we had in there that would have drove it  to $2.9 billion was Australia, $600 million. We feel good about the opportunity. The balance about a little bit beyond that. That was the key driver of brining down our international pipeline to about $2.6 billion. But it's still sitting at a very robust level, and which gives us some confidence of growth in fiscal '18 as a company overall.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our total pension deficit, Gautham, increased by $100 million to $2.3 billion from $2.2 billion, and this includes both the pension and the open liabilities. So we had previously said that our pension liabilities increased about roughly $180-ish m
componenttext: Yes. So our total pension deficit, Gautham, increased by $100 million to $2.3 billion from $2.2 billion, and this includes both the pension and the open liabilities. So we had previously said that our pension liabilities increased about roughly $180-ish million, from every 25 basis points reduction in discount rate. And the discount rate changed by 40 basis points given that was partially offset by the contribution we had made and certain changes in the postretirement benefit. So our total deficit ended at $2.3 billion, up $100 million from 20 -- where we ended last year. It really is no impact on contributions to go that kind of a different formula. Total countermeasures will go up a little bit next year because discount rate at which we calculate with the contributions, is coming down. And also the rate of return and assets need to be factored in. So contributions are up about $10 million, $15 million year-over-year. But that also gets offset by the reimbursements that we get from the government.
