headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Harris Corporation's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Harris Corporation's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Pamela Padgett, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Rahul Ghai, Senior Vice President and CFO.First, a few words on forward-looking
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Call. I'm Pamela Padgett, and on the call today is Bill Brown, Chairman and CEO; and Rahul Ghai, Senior Vice President and CFO.
First, a few words on forward-looking. Forward-looking statements made today involve assumptions, risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those statements. For more information and the related discussion, please see the press release, the presentation and Harris' SEC filings. In addition, a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed today to comparable GAAP measures is included in the quarterly materials on the Investor Relations section of our website, which is www.harris.com, where a replay of this call also will be available.
All right, Bill, with that, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning, everyone. Harris began fiscal '17 with a good start out of the gate, and we're executing well against our key strategic priorities. So I'll begin with a quick update about how we're delivering on them. As part
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you, Pam, and good morning, everyone. Harris began fiscal '17 with a good start out of the gate, and we're executing well against our key strategic priorities. So I'll begin with a quick update about how we're delivering on them. As part of an ongoing initiative to optimize our business portfolio, we announced earlier this morning a definitive agreement to sell the CapRock Commercial business for $425 million and plan to use the proceeds to pay down debt and repurchase shares. Portfolio shaping supports our strategy to invest in businesses where Harris can provide technology differentiation. And we'll continue to review our portfolio and objectively assess which businesses are a strategic fit and which businesses have better value under a different ownership structure.
We also remain committed to smart and balanced capital deployment, and in the first quarter, we used $100 million in cash to repurchase shares and we increased the dividend 6%, our 15th consecutive annual increase. We also repaid $33 million in term debt, and in early October we retired a $250 million bond that was due, making further progress towards our 3-year debt reduction goal of $2 billion, and we're about halfway there.
We remain laser focused on Exelis' integration and capturing synergies and related accretion, and through Q1, we're tracking well towards capturing $50 million of additional in-year saving, and achieving our target of $140 million to $150 million in run rate savings as we exit fiscal '17. And while all integration projects are complete or well underway, we'll continue to find ways to lower cost and drive productivity as part of our normal operational excellence agenda.
And then finally, investing in R&D and new product development to grow core franchises and expanding the close adjacencies has been an important part of our strategy. And in the first quarter, R&D spending was up 7% and over 4% of revenue. For the year, we still expect to spend about 4% of revenue, similar to fiscal '16 and at a level well above our peers.
So turning now to Q1 results. Non-GAAP earnings per share was $1.39, up 6% on a 2% organic revenue decline. Despite the revenue headwind and higher R&D spending in the quarter, operating margin increased 50 basis points as a result of higher synergies, productivity savings and pension income. Earnings per share also benefited from a lower tax rate in the first quarter.
Revenue reflected continued growth in Space and Intel, up 4%, and Electronic Systems up 2%, while Communications Systems was down 5% and Critical Networks was down 7%.
Orders were particularly strong with total company book-to-bill of 1.17 and funded backlog of 6% over the prior quarter. Book-to-bill for each segment was above 1, and within Communications Systems, we saw a strong recovery in our legacy tactical business where book-to-bill was 1.22. Healthy bookings plus several opportunities that slipped from the back half of fiscal '16 drew our backlog up 16% sequentially to $467 million and higher in both DoD and international.
Q1 revenue in legacy tactical was also encouraging at down 1% with DoD revenue up 4% and international down 4%. Within DoD, higher first quarter revenue was primarily related to achieving important milestones early in the year for MNVR and MUOS. We received a limited rate production authorization on MNVR, which is our mid-tier networking radio; and formal NSA certification for running the MUOS satellite wave form on existing Falcon III 117Gs, which triggered initial fielding of MUOS capability.
Also in the quarter, the Army contracted Harris to develop the narrowband mode for the Soldier Radio Waveform or SRW, a requirement for all Army modernization radios, the Manpack, the Rifleman, the MNVR and the future SANR or Small Airborne Networking Radio. This contract demonstrates Harris' leadership and expertise in adapting complex waveforms to meet the changing requirements of the Army's tactical network.
In legacy international, revenue trended favorably against our full year guidance and was higher in Europe, Central and Latin America or CALA and Asia Pacific, but was offset, as anticipated, by lower revenue in Central Asia and the Middle East Africa regions.
You'll recall that Europe was strong in fiscal '16, driven primarily by Eastern European countries, and that trend continued in Q1 with encouraging signs for the balance of the year. The CALA region is benefiting from the country's modernization of next-gen radios and a new $90 million contract win from U.S. Southern command supporting counter narcotics missions in Latin America. And in Asia Pac, we're supplying HF and multiband radio to support maritime capability in the Southeast Asian country as part of an ongoing trend of the U.S. bolstering partner capabilities in the region and a significant opportunity remains on the horizon in Australia. So overall, regional trends of strength and headwinds attracting about as we laid out in our 3Q and 4Q earnings calls and while still early in the year, represents a good start towards achieving our full year guidance. 
Turning to Space and Intel. We've another quarter of excellent wins from customers in the intelligence community, which continues to be a solid growth area for the company. In the quarter, Harris won a $25 million initial contract to develop a multimission small satellite for a classified customer, our second government win in this area. SmallSats are emerging as a low cost solution to a rapidly changing threat environment, offering a shorter development cycle and launched at a fraction of the cost and lead time of a large exclusive satellite. Our offering in this growing niche is powerful, combining a portfolio of advanced sensors, software-defined radio technology to support onboard mission changes and Harris' agility to quickly innovate as threats evolve.
We also continue to build on our franchise in Space Superiority. Following the close of the quarter, Harris was selected for $53 million in follow-on work to provide counter communication capabilities that detect adversary interference and take action to protect our space assets. This new win will bring contracts to date for this mission to about $200 million.
And then outside the intelligence community, we received a $90 million follow-on contract to provide navigation payloads for GPS Space -- III Space Vehicles 9 and 10. We're already under contract to deliver payloads for SV 1 through 8 and we're investing to develop a fully digital solution for 11 through 32. 
Turning to Electronic Systems. Q1 marked the third consecutive quarter of strong bookings for electronic warfare, winning modernizations on legacy platforms where we have strong incumbency positions. And as the EW capability gap between the U.S. and peer countries has narrowed, modernizations on deployed fleets have become a higher priority. We've included a $22 million contract for the B-1B and a 3-year $55 million contract to redesign the electronic warfare system for the B-52. B-52 wins over last 2 years now stand at about $200 million, and we continue to see strong future opportunities on fleets with long modernization tails.
In Critical Networks, Harris expanded its reach into a new market by leveraging a strong and long successful history with the FAA for designing and maintaining highly secure communication networks.
Following the close of the quarter, Harris was awarded a 14-year $700 million ceiling IDIQ from the state of Florida to provide a statewide secure communications network. This network called MyFloridaNet-2 will have about 4,000 sites connecting public safety, law enforcement and other state and local government agencies.
And with that, let me now turn the call over to Rahul for more financial detail and guidance. Rahul?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. And good morning, everyone. Just to remind you, discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis and supplements GAAP results in our other quarterly earnings materials.Turning now to segment details on Slide 4. Communication Systems segment re
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. And good morning, everyone. Just to remind you, discussions today are on a non-GAAP basis and supplements GAAP results in our other quarterly earnings materials.
Turning now to segment details on Slide 4. Communication Systems segment revenue was $431 million and down 5% compared to the prior year. Tactical Communications was down 6%, primarily as a result of lower international SINCGARS sales. Public Safety was down 1%. Operating income was $119 million compared with $138 million in the prior year, driven by lower volume and mix.
On Slide 10, we have again included historical information for legacy tactical, orders, revenue and backlog.
Space and Intelligence Systems on Slide 5. Revenue was $453 million and up 4% compared to prior year. This was driven by higher revenue from intelligence community customers and from Radiation Budget Instrument program called RBI to provide sensors for monitoring climate change and global warming on NASA's Joint Polar Satellite System. Operating income was $80 million compared with $68 million in the prior year, driven by continued strong program performance and higher pension income.
Electronic Systems on Slide 6. Revenue was $361 million and up 2% on an organic basis compared to prior year, excluding $90 million of revenue from Aerostructures business that was divested in the fourth quarter of fiscal '16.
Higher revenue from initial ramp of recently awarded integrated Battle Management Systems in Middle East and from electronic warfare solutions was partially offset by lower wireless product sales. Operating income was $74 million compared with $69 million in the prior year. In addition to the electronic warfare contract that Bill mentioned, Harris received $35 million in follow-on contract for the F-35 program.
Critical Networks on Slide 7. Revenue was $527 million and down 7% compared to prior year. Higher revenue from FAA's NextGen modernization program was more than offset by lower revenue in IT Services down $30 million and in CapRock's commercial business down $25 million. IT Services revenue was in line with expectations of it stabilizing in the $225 million to $250 million per quarter range. And CapRock Commercial is now at approximately $75 million per quarter. Operating income was $66 million compared with $63 million in the prior year.
On top of what was already mentioned, Harris was awarded a 5-year $125 million, single award IDIQ for IT Services from a classified customer. This extends a 25-year relationship and reflects a business development focus in the intelligence community.
Moving to Slides 8 and 9. Fiscal '17 guidance remains unchanged with GAAP EPS guidance in a range of $1.553 to $1.573 and non-GAAP EPS in a range of $1.570 to $1.590. As previously communicated, EPS guidance reflects $150 million in share repurchases for the year.
Total company revenue guidance is unchanged in the range of $7.1 billion to $7.3 billion, down 1% to 4% on an organic basis, excluding revenue from Aerostructures divestiture. Outlook for segment and other details outlined in the slide also remain unchanged, including generating an expected $800 million in free cash flow for the full year.
Although the first quarter tax rate was 27.5%, we still expect a full year tax rate of 31%. Our expected 31% rate reflected adoption of a new accounting standard with stock compensation and the benefit of it primarily in the first quarter. The remaining 3 quarters are expected to average 32% weighting quarter-to-quarter depending on specific tax timing differences. We will update fiscal '17 guidance once CapRock transaction closes.
Now I'll just hand back to Bill for a few closing comments.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, Rahul. Overall, we had a good start to the year, delivering solid financial results and making excellent progress on our key strategic priorities. We're maintaining guidance for the year and we anticipate that the continuing resolut
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you, Rahul. Overall, we had a good start to the year, delivering solid financial results and making excellent progress on our key strategic priorities. We're maintaining guidance for the year and we anticipate that the continuing resolution will extend through the balance of the calendar year and constrain spending as it typically does until a budget is passed. We'll continue to enhance shareholder value by optimizing our business portfolio, deleveraging, reinvesting to drive future growth and allocating capital in a shareholder-friendly way.
And with that, I'd like to ask the operator to open the line for questions.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Seth Seifman of JPMorgan.

componenttext: I'm not sure how much you can comment on it, but there've been reports in the press about potentially divesting other portions of the Critical Networks business. I wondered, can you talk a little bit more about your vision for that business specifically in the future.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Seth, thank you for the question. I'm not going to comment on any potential plans. We simply don't -- we don't do that. I think we feel good about the transaction we're announcing today on selling the CapRock commercial business. And you know we've
componenttext: Well, Seth, thank you for the question. I'm not going to comment on any potential plans. We simply don't -- we don't do that. I think we feel good about the transaction we're announcing today on selling the CapRock commercial business. And you know we've got a pretty strong track record here looking pretty objectively at the businesses that we're in and assessing which fit, which do not. And I take you back to the Broadcast business and Commercial Health Care and Aerostructures and now the commercial CapRock business. And we continue to look pretty objectively at the portfolio that we have and assess what fits and what does not. I would say that I have been pretty consistent in commenting that we want to be in businesses where technology can differentiate our offering in the marketplace, that's very important to us. Of course, we look at strategic fit and performance of the business but that is certainly the bar and the milestone that we're tracking there and we'll see more as the time goes on, but nothing more to report today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up and more in the model. In communications systems, it's a nice quarter for the tactical radios. The margin overall for the segment was a little below your guidance for the year. Is that reflecting R&D or m
componenttext: Okay, okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up and more in the model. In communications systems, it's a nice quarter for the tactical radios. The margin overall for the segment was a little below your guidance for the year. Is that reflecting R&D or mix? Or what's going to change through the course of the year to bring that margin up?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It reflects both. I mean, it's down year-over-year. It's flat sequentially. Part of it is volume in the tactical comms business, not just radio but tactical comms. It's a bit less favorable mix. We have slightly more sustainment services business in
componenttext: Yes. It reflects both. I mean, it's down year-over-year. It's flat sequentially. Part of it is volume in the tactical comms business, not just radio but tactical comms. It's a bit less favorable mix. We have slightly more sustainment services business in Q1 and a little more front-end loaded R&D, which should mitigate a little bit over the course of the year. Of course, these things move quarter-to-quarter, but over the balance of the year, we'll expect better mix and we do expect it to achieve the guidance margins for the year at 30% -- about 30%.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: I was hoping to go back to CapRock. I was just wondering if you expect that to be accretive to or dilutive and then what could be the cash proceeds from that sale.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're selling for $425 million so cash will be a little bit below that, but it's probably over $400 million. We're going to use it for both debt paydown and share repurchases, probably a little bit more than half on debt, a little less than half on share
componenttext: We're selling for $425 million so cash will be a little bit below that, but it's probably over $400 million. We're going to use it for both debt paydown and share repurchases, probably a little bit more than half on debt, a little less than half on share buybacks. On an annual basis, we would expect it to be about $0.04 dilutive.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then it seems like you had a couple of good quarters in terms of bookings for electronic warfare. I was hoping you could maybe size that business and what we can expect for the outlook going forward.
componenttext: And then it seems like you had a couple of good quarters in terms of bookings for electronic warfare. I was hoping you could maybe size that business and what we can expect for the outlook going forward.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we feel really good about the performance in electronic warfare, had really strong bookings really throughout last year. Orders doubled, backlog grew quite a bit, the book-to-bill was stronger than 1. And coming out of the first quarter, it was good
componenttext: Yes, we feel really good about the performance in electronic warfare, had really strong bookings really throughout last year. Orders doubled, backlog grew quite a bit, the book-to-bill was stronger than 1. And coming out of the first quarter, it was good revenue growth but also good strong bookings. We feel very good about that business. This is -- again we've got very strong positions in a number of legacy platforms that require modernization upgrades. There's new threats on the horizon. Our military's talked quite a bit about that and our aircraft need to be upgraded, and we certainly have a great position on F-18. We're on international F-16 in large aircrafts like B-1B, C-130 and the B-52 has been an important driver of our bookings and future growth. So we feel very good about where we're at today on electronic warfare. We continue to invest in smaller size leading power platforms. We've got a good position on the classified side. And over time, when you pair up Harris' front-end phased array technology with electronic warfare capabilities from Exelis in the back end, that capability is pretty special. So we feel good about where we stand today in electronic warfare.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that about half of Electronic Systems? Is that a fair estimate?
componenttext: Is that about half of Electronic Systems? Is that a fair estimate?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little less than that. Yes, that the -- yes, it's about $500 million, $550 million in that range.
componenttext: A little less than that. Yes, that the -- yes, it's about $500 million, $550 million in that range.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Pete Skibitski with Drexel Hamilton.

componenttext: Bill, did first quarter sales come in a little stronger than you expected just because of the CR kind of ongoing? Or do you think you'll feel the impact more toward the second quarter because that's the first fiscal quarter of the government's year?

componenttext: I am sorry, Pete. I think the phone is breaking up. Well, I think you are at the front-end of it. Somehow, something coming in stronger. Can you say that one more time.

componenttext: Yes, sorry. I was just wondering if your first quarter sales came in a little stronger than you expected because of the CR, or do you think that the CR will impact more so your second quarter because that's the first fiscal quarter of the government's year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we see sort of going back a number of years, is we've been operating under CR, it's the beginning of the government fiscal year. So we tend to see some end of year money getting spent, bookings and revenue, and tends to slow down a little bit in the
componenttext: Well, we see sort of going back a number of years, is we've been operating under CR, it's the beginning of the government fiscal year. So we tend to see some end of year money getting spent, bookings and revenue, and tends to slow down a little bit in the second quarter. So we would expect a normal friction. We'd see in our Q2 as we typically have seen in a CR -- under a CR, including in the back half of the year.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard with Vertical Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard with Vertical Research.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, you highlighted the very strong book-to-bill in the quarter. I was wondering if, of the orders you've taken in the last 3 months, what is the lead time on this. Is it any different from what you normally expect. I mean, what we're obviously looking
componenttext: Bill, you highlighted the very strong book-to-bill in the quarter. I was wondering if, of the orders you've taken in the last 3 months, what is the lead time on this. Is it any different from what you normally expect. I mean, what we're obviously looking for is when does this convert into revenues?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is the bookings we saw, which were pretty good on the tactical side, are relatively quick turn orders. I mean, that's a short-cycle business. So the majority of that will turn in the year and that's positive for us, but it depends on the busine
componenttext: Well, this is the bookings we saw, which were pretty good on the tactical side, are relatively quick turn orders. I mean, that's a short-cycle business. So the majority of that will turn in the year and that's positive for us, but it depends on the business. There are some parts of the company that are longer cycle. The very long -- the big order we got in State of Florida is going to happen over the next decade effectively. Some of the EW orders are going to be over the next 3, 4 years. So it depends on the business. Our longer cycle businesses tend to be in the ES segment and Space and Intel segment. And of course, the shorter cycle orders are going to come in our tactical or CS side.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then the second question you mentioned in the past that the Middle East, Central Asia and Africa have been softer markets for you on the radio side recently. Has there been any sign of that stabilizing as yet?
componenttext: Okay, and then the second question you mentioned in the past that the Middle East, Central Asia and Africa have been softer markets for you on the radio side recently. Has there been any sign of that stabilizing as yet?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not seeing anything better today than we did over the last 3 to 6 months. It's the same factors that we've been talking about that continue to impact that region. Certainly, low oil prices would seem to be going down even further or causing bu
componenttext: Well, we're not seeing anything better today than we did over the last 3 to 6 months. It's the same factors that we've been talking about that continue to impact that region. Certainly, low oil prices would seem to be going down even further or causing budgetary pressures. We know the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, it's driving some instability. Some of the funding is going more towards munitions than communications, but I would say that we've seen some opportunities from up in a couple of areas like Jordan and the UAE. In Jordan, we booked an order here in the first quarter. We see more opportunities on the horizon. Saudi continues at a relatively low level, '16 came down from '15, but we don't see a big step down in '17. Right now it's running at a relatively low level as we see it. There's some pressure in Iraq just because of the strike in the country, but the opportunity we see on the horizon in Iraq are very, very sizable. It's probably the biggest opportunity overall in our long-term pipeline. So it's a mixed bag within the Middle East, but not much of the story has changed over the last 3 to 6 months. Some of the slips that happened from '16 into '17 we have started to book and we'll continue to do that in Q2 and Q3. So thank you, Rob.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Co.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Gautam Khanna with Cowen and Co.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions. First, last quarter, if I recall, Bill, you mentioned there was $65 million to $70 million of shipments that slipped into the first fiscal quarter. And I was wondering did you, in fact, catch those all up. And were those booke
componenttext: I had a couple of questions. First, last quarter, if I recall, Bill, you mentioned there was $65 million to $70 million of shipments that slipped into the first fiscal quarter. And I was wondering did you, in fact, catch those all up. And were those booked in the current -- in the September quarter? Or were those in the backlog as of June 30?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we said around -- it was around $60 million worth of orders had -- which did not happen in Q4. About half was -- a little more than half was international and that did slip into the year into Q1. So it was like $30 million, $35 million, in th
componenttext: Yes, I think we said around -- it was around $60 million worth of orders had -- which did not happen in Q4. About half was -- a little more than half was international and that did slip into the year into Q1. So it was like $30 million, $35 million, in that range. And yes, we picked those up in Q1 effectively as part of our release. The other part was the DoD side, and that was just general slowness and some friction cautious buying behavior on the part of some of the acquisition folks. So that was not necessarily a slip, but certainly, the international piece that moved into Q1 did happen.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that was the book and ship in the September quarter?
componenttext: And that was the book and ship in the September quarter?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Largely, yes.
componenttext: Largely, yes.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Could you talk a little bit about the tax basis of your IT service business? And could you size it for us. I believe it's about $1.03 billion, but wanted to get your sense for that. Also what the tax leakage will be with the CapRock sale, how much w
componenttext: Okay. Could you talk a little bit about the tax basis of your IT service business? And could you size it for us. I believe it's about $1.03 billion, but wanted to get your sense for that. Also what the tax leakage will be with the CapRock sale, how much will you actually net in terms of proceeds?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not going to comment on the tax basis or service, but service is around $1 million business and there's no tax leakage on the CapRock transaction.
componenttext: Yes, I'm not going to comment on the tax basis or service, but service is around $1 million business and there's no tax leakage on the CapRock transaction.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, previously you've updated us on some of the major campaigns like the JTRS Manpack radio timing. I wondered if, a, when is that going to happen? And do you think it will still be 2 awardees? Relatedly, if you could talk about when Australia might
componenttext: And also, previously you've updated us on some of the major campaigns like the JTRS Manpack radio timing. I wondered if, a, when is that going to happen? And do you think it will still be 2 awardees? Relatedly, if you could talk about when Australia might actually book some orders, is that still in fiscal Q4 this year? And maybe any of the other sizable campaigns that we should be tracking.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, let me start with Australia. I mean, it's still a big opportunity on the horizon and it's on the order in total about $600 million, a little less than that, but they decided to split it into 2 pieces, as I mentioned on the last call, and we sti
componenttext: Well, yes, let me start with Australia. I mean, it's still a big opportunity on the horizon and it's on the order in total about $600 million, a little less than that, but they decided to split it into 2 pieces, as I mentioned on the last call, and we still expect about half a book towards the back end of our fiscal year, the other sometime into '18 or beyond. So we feel very good about the progress there and our position on that particular opportunity. On the Manpack, it continues to progress. We are one of 3 awardees, a very sizable contract. We completed the qualification tests. The customer testing should happen early in fiscal '17, so in the next 3 or 4 months. And then it will go into a delivery order procurement we'll be, might made by -- decision would be made by August, I believe, of next year with deliveries off of that starting about a year from now and then continuing into early calendar '18. So that has not moved out in terms of the delivery time frame on the back end. On the other one, which was -- which is important is Rifleman. We're one of 2 vendors, us and Thales, and you recall it's a $3.9 billion IDIQ. We've gotten through a qual test and customer test. It was for a single channel radio, but if you recall, they left a big part of the overall award value with an opportunity for a 2-channel radio, and it does sound like the Army is looking to perhaps accelerate the purchase of a 2-channel radio. They saw the opportunity with the radio we have with SOCOM, which is a single vendor award that we have as Harris Corporation. They saw the radio. There's a possibility they will accelerate the purchase of a 2-channel radio, which I think would be relatively good news for Harris since we're well positioned on that particular opportunity. And you saw in Q1 or as I mentioned in Q1 that we got a milestone sea approval on the mid-tier radio with half of the opportunity recognized in Q1. The other half will come sometime later in our fiscal '17. So overall, I think good progress. MUOS, we're very pleased with receiving NSA cert and to see initial fielding of that capability. Keep in mind, there's 30,000, 117Gs in the field that have the possibility of being upgraded with the MUOS waveform. And as that happens, since the development is all behind us and it's a software load, it comes down to us at a relatively high margin. So all of which I think is good progress in the quarter, Gautam. The last one I would mention is on SOCOM, I think it's a very important one. That's a 2-channel radio and that continues to progress. We're investing in it and we still see that on track for deliveries about a year from now.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Bill, so you've mentioned or you've gone through a lot of detail on a number of moving pieces into your potential future order flow. I wonder if you would just, if you're able to tell us if you think the total company book-to-bill and also specifically the legacy tactical radio book-to-bill will be above 1 for the full year fiscal '17?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's certainly the trajectory that we're on and the hope that we have. Right now we came out of the gates in Q1 very, very strong, and I think we're pleased about that. And we always hope for as we expect growth in '18 and beyond. We certainly hope for
componenttext: That's certainly the trajectory that we're on and the hope that we have. Right now we came out of the gates in Q1 very, very strong, and I think we're pleased about that. And we always hope for as we expect growth in '18 and beyond. We certainly hope for good positive bookings this quarter as that would -- this year that would lead us into growth in '18.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. As a follow-up to the question on the Middle East contribution to the legacy tactical radio business, is it possible to quantify what the peak-to-trough has already been in that revenue stream, just so we can get a sense of how much lower that could
componenttext: Okay. As a follow-up to the question on the Middle East contribution to the legacy tactical radio business, is it possible to quantify what the peak-to-trough has already been in that revenue stream, just so we can get a sense of how much lower that could go, or maybe if it's approaching a floor just because enough of the decline has already happened?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think let's see -- we're probably down about 40% peak-to-trough at this point. And from the way that we see it today, the Middle East should -- may be down slightly more again in '17, but it depends on the timing of some opportunities in Iraq. Agai
componenttext: Yes. I think let's see -- we're probably down about 40% peak-to-trough at this point. And from the way that we see it today, the Middle East should -- may be down slightly more again in '17, but it depends on the timing of some opportunities in Iraq. Again, Jordan looks pretty good. UAE looks pretty good. A couple of other things are progressing pretty well in the quarter what we see in the balance of the year. And the funding support from U.S. government still remains pretty robust, so we don't see a big step-down in the Middle East, but that's where we see it today.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And so what is that run rating then as a percentage of your legacy tactical radio business after that 40% peak-to-trough?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And so what is that run rating then as a percentage of your legacy tactical radio business after that 40% peak-to-trough?

componenttext: It's about on the order around 25%, 30% of the international business. In the international, about 2/3 of the total tactical, legacy tactical. So it will be a little bit less than that, of course.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And what is SINCGARS down to at this point?
componenttext: Okay, great. And what is SINCGARS down to at this point?

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's at a relatively low rate. It's mostly international business. It -- there's still some sustainment work going on with the U.S. Military, but a lot of that business is international and is experiencing some of the same challenges in our legacy tactica
componenttext: It's at a relatively low rate. It's mostly international business. It -- there's still some sustainment work going on with the U.S. Military, but a lot of that business is international and is experiencing some of the same challenges in our legacy tactical business, a lot is being sold into the Middle East. And as you know, we talked about a pretty good opportunity that's been sitting out on the horizon in Saudi Arabia. It's in the $40 million to $50 million range for SINCGARS and that still remains towards the back end of the year, but that would be the next big opportunity on the horizon. It's a relatively low rate.

componenttext: It's relatively small. I think it's in tens of millions at this point. So it's going to be low for this quarter. It will come lower as we roll this thing out, it will come in phases.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is a very big important opportunity for us because today we're on the state law enforcement radio system in Florida, we have been doing that for 15 years. Now through 10 hurricanes without a single outage. So we feel very good about that. And that cr
componenttext: This is a very big important opportunity for us because today we're on the state law enforcement radio system in Florida, we have been doing that for 15 years. Now through 10 hurricanes without a single outage. So we feel very good about that. And that credibility, alongside of our reputation with the FAA, allowed us to beat a very large telco out of a pretty substantial contract, interconnecting a bunch of offices in the state of Florida. So we feel very good about the position that we happen to be in here and it's going to roll itself out over the next decade or so.

componenttext: Okay. And is there plans to -- you mentioned with the proceeds of CapRock to repay debt, I mean, what is sort of the longer-term plan here? headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as Bill mentioned, our current plan is that we would use slightly more than half the proceeds to pay down debt and slightly less than half for share buyback. What we have to -- what we are balancing here, Gautam, is just we have a high debt-to-EBITDA r
componenttext: So as Bill mentioned, our current plan is that we would use slightly more than half the proceeds to pay down debt and slightly less than half for share buyback. What we have to -- what we are balancing here, Gautam, is just we have a high debt-to-EBITDA ratio than we have commitments to our debt rating agency. So we are balancing that and we have an aggressive debt buyback, debt paydown goal. So that is the objective at this point.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we expect it to be over 1, and I think that was a comment I was trying to make earlier today, which is, as we go forward into and think about fiscal '18, we still see some important elements that will drive growth. We see good performance in our lon
componenttext: Well, we expect it to be over 1, and I think that was a comment I was trying to make earlier today, which is, as we go forward into and think about fiscal '18, we still see some important elements that will drive growth. We see good performance in our longer cycle businesses in Space and Intel, in Electronic Systems. We came off of a back half of '16 with good growth. We had good orders. We ended with higher backlog. We came out of Q1 with good growth, higher backlog, good orders, and that will carry us into fiscal '18. As we go through this year and we look out into '18, we still see strong army modernization opportunity, SOCOM modernization opportunities. Australia will start to come into the picture. And we still see good opportunities to grow that business in fiscal '18. So that would require us to have a pretty solid bookings through the year. We're early in the year. We had a great start.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Well above 1? Or -- I'm not trying to be annoying, I'm just asking because what you've sized in the later part of this fiscal year could be fairly substantial contract awards. I mean the $300 million award from Australia would move the needle presumably, I'm just wondering is a 1.2 out of the question? Or I mean over 1 just seems like a low bar at this point, so I'm just...

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, it's also early in the year. I mean, you don't win a football game in the first quarter. We've got 3 more to go, and I'll give you -- I'll continue to give you on an update on the way we see the market, the environment, the opportunities we're ch
componenttext: I'd say, it's also early in the year. I mean, you don't win a football game in the first quarter. We've got 3 more to go, and I'll give you -- I'll continue to give you on an update on the way we see the market, the environment, the opportunities we're chasing. As we go through the year, I think as we've done pretty clearly over the last couple of years, we'll communicate as much as we can. But right now we expect and our folks up in the tactical business expect that we'll have a good year and a book-to-bill over 1. And that's, I think at this point, that's all we're able to communicate.

componenttext: This is actually Ruben on for Carter. Bill, do you think you can speak to more specifically, I guess like how much op profit and EBITDA you expect to be leaving with the CapRock business here? I just wanted to try to get my head around some of the metrics of this deal.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We expect revenue in that CapRock Commercial business this year at about $300 million. We did about $75 million and we were sort of at a level run rate through the year, so about $300 million. And it's a mid-single-digit ROS business, so call it, 5%
componenttext: Sure. We expect revenue in that CapRock Commercial business this year at about $300 million. We did about $75 million and we were sort of at a level run rate through the year, so about $300 million. And it's a mid-single-digit ROS business, so call it, 5% to 6%. And it's got $35 million, $37 million just of D&A. So those -- that could help you with some of the metrics.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, everyone. Thank you so much for joining us this morning.
componenttext: All right, everyone. Thank you so much for joining us this morning.

headline: Harris Corporation, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This does conclude the program, and you may all disconnect. Everyone have a great day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating in today's conference. This does conclude the program, and you may all disconnect. Everyone have a great day.
